Everything just needed a bit more punch in seasoning, though I thought the mock meats were good substitutions for the real thing. Does it compare to real meat? Definitely not, but again that's not what we are here for. The portion sizes were bigger than expected. For instance, the turnip cakes came in a portion for 3, the lotus leave rice was in 2. It was a bit much for just 2 people, but if you're with 3 or 4 people, it's perfect.

Overall, a good variety of dim sum, but lacking in flavor a bit. I don't say that because it's not real meat though. I used a lot of soy sauce and such, but I wish I didn't have to. On the other hand, I'd be happy to return, but I'm more eager to try other dimsum spots first.

I am so, so sad to update this review, but the place is no longer the same.  Some time around 2021 they must have changed ownership.  The food is still okay, but no longer great.  A lot of our favorite items are too mushy or flavorless or just completely different.  Not a bad place to eat if you are around there, but no reason to make a special trip.

The staff were friendly and the service quick, but the food was abysmal. We were incredibly excited at the idea of vegetarian dim sum, but we ordered four dishes and, after tasting each, left it all and wound up going out for dinner a second time since we couldn't imagine eating what we were served. Textures were horrid, food was oily and excessively sweet. Save your money and go somewhere else. We regret having visited.

Was really pleased with the quality of the dim sum here. Especially liked the mushroom rice rolls and the bean curd rolls. The bbq pork also does not disappoint! Three stars because they used so many single-use plastic items. Definitely can be more environmentally friendly.

Maybe it was because I came on a weeknight, but I was not a fan of this place. Buddha Bodai is my go-to vegetarian dim sum place in Chinatown, and they're way better. Just a short walk away too!

This place just oozes old school Chinatown. It's dimly lit. The walls are a disgusting shade of green. None of the chairs match and are on the edge of being broken. The ceiling consists of office-style drop tiles.

The food also wasn't great. Their menu is pretty confusing if you don't read Chinese. They call things super random other things. For instance, what most places call taro dumplings, they call mashed taro treasure boxes. Why? Also, those sucked. They were sour for some reason.

The pan fried turnip cakes were also weird and amorphous. I don't understand how they fucked that up. With the exception of the dried shrimp, turnip cakes are ALREADY vegetarian! Theirs were incredibly gloopy and hard to eat.

The vegetarian har gow (shrimp dumplings) were also not great. The "shrimp" was completely tasteless. The texture was shrimp-like, but that was about it.

But hey, I guess if you're with people with dietary restrictions and it's late, this place is good to have around as a third or fourth option. Cash only though.

Two of the three dim sum items I ordered were cold and not steamed through. The rice flour dough on all the items were too thick; I had to dig through to get to the filling, and left lots of dough on my plate.
What's more, the servers were spraying bleach cleaner on the tables. In a poorly ventilated restaurant, the bleach fumes were perceptible while we ate.
It took everything in me to not tell the couple who were seated nearby to leave and save themselves from wasting time and money.

After asking three times during ordering if the dishes contained peanuts. The server assured us there was none. We even translated peanut allergy into mandarin to be sure the server could understand. Low and behold there was peanuts because my friend with a severe allergy started to react. We approached the staff again to stress the importance. " no peanuts no peanuts" until my friend said " I can die if I have peanuts" the staff responded "ok a little peanut in the sauce" the fact that staff would lie about an ingredient that could kill my friend is disgusting. She had to use her epi pen outside the restaurant and was crying. Would never come back here. Lack of integrity

I like to be fair. And I really don't like to leave bad reviews. I stumbled upon this place with a friend after walking around aimlessly trying to settle on a place to eat. What sold this place to her was the spinach dumplings. For me personally, I would've preferred to stick to a place that sells meat dishes but I figured why not?

Upon entering, the atmosphere was weird. There was no music playing overhead. No noise from a TV or kitchen background noise. You could only hear the conversations the other customers here were engaging in. The hostess/waitress greeted us, asked to see our vaccination cards and took us to our table. Once at our table, I have a tendency to look at everything, on our table, on the walls, the customers, you know trying to take it all in. The place looked a tad dingy. The walls were covered in green paint/wallpaper. The carpet looked like it hadn't seen the vacuum or a nice clean in a while. I could've overlooked these factors until my fingers touched our table. I subconsciously decided to slide my finger on the table and I could tell it hadn't been cleaned in a while. It had this thick layer on the surface of something I can't even name. Although it felt dirty, nothing gross visibly appeared on my finger so I was relieved. I also decided to touch the plates and utensils on our table. They also felt like they hadn't been properly washed.

The menu is of course vegetarian. They do however, offer some mock meat dishes but I decided to not risk my chances with those dishes. My friend ordered the spinach dumplings and a vegetarian wonton soup. The spinach dumplings were terrible. The doughy exterior was thick and tasteless. Although I didn't get to taste the wonton soup. My friend enjoyed it more than the dumplings. I had the pan fried noodles with broccoli. That was delicious. I was glad that it turned out great.

Putting the vegetarian menu aside, I wouldn't really come back here or recommend. There are other places that sell meat and veggie options. The prices for the food are great. Our bill didn't go over $40. And although I have nothing to complain in regards to the service (our waitress, the only one, was pretty on top of her stuff), I wasn't really impressed by the place despite the location.

So good. Our eyes were bigger than our stomachs and we ordered way too much food. The menu had so many amazing things we, wanted to try them all. The only complains that they only take cash and we didn't know that going in.

I hate that I have to write this review because it is a hard time for many small businesses.
Maybe it was just an "off day" and this isn't the norm for the restaurant, but eating at Vegetarian Dim Sum House was a very unpleasant dining experience in terms of the quality of food.
Indoors has a strange musty smell (like a combination of damp towels and dust) so we switched to sitting outside in the cold. Unfortunately, that scent carried over into the taste of all of the dishes we had ordered and consequently made every bite inedible.

As a former vegan, I have had faux seafood and meat before and the imitation shrimp and pork tasted nothing like what was expected.

Unfortunately, the food was so bad that we don't see ourselves returning or recommending the restaurant. Besides the food, the service is rather fast and accommodating.

My best friend/foodie partner is vegetarian so we've always stayed away from dim sum despite how much I love it. We stumbled on this place a few weeks ago and fell in love. It is so inexpensive, absolutely delicious and has an incredible variety.

As someone who eats meat I did miss some of the usual dim sum specialties but my friend LOVED it. Couldn't have found a better place for us. Super quick service, we ordered take out and none of it was soggy or cold by the time we got home.

This place is the original Vegetarian dim sum restaurant in Chinatown Manhattan. Gave it a go after trying the other more popular Vegetarian dim sum spot.

My first impression is that the restaurant is more old school style. Decor is non-existent and it looks dark indoor despite all the lights were on and it was day time when I visited.

Taste wise, the braised beancurd with rice was good. The Buddha beancurd rolls and fried taro treasure box were meh.....Prices were also significantly higher than the other popular vegan spot in Chinatown.  

I will opt to go to the more popular spot instead.

Picked this spot on a post lunchtime window Saturday afternoon. The place serves all vegetarian items even though the menu says "Chicken". The ambiance is alright and looks like it hasn't been done up in a long long time. We were seated immediately and served some hot tea which was delightful . Decided to order Pan fried dumplings and Szechuan Chicken.

The pan fried dumplings were huge and stayed true to the fried part with quite some oil. This is the opposite of healthy. With the dipping sauce it tasted pretty good. Would recommend this if you like slightly chewy pan fried dumplings.

The chicken was actually a wheat based mock meat (possibly Seitan) stuffed with mushroom. I expected the dish to come with a side of rice but that wasn't the case. The dish itself lacked that punch that I was expecting out of Szechuan and was mostly a lot of oil and soy. With close to $18 for the price, I feel the dish was not at all worth it.

My suggestion would be to stick to what they do best , dumplings. Good options for those vegetarians out there.

Treasure balls (3) - Don't order this. There is no treasure. Just large Chinese potato balls.

Vegeterian mock shrimp dumplings (4) - Average.

Vegetarian mock roast pork buns (3) - I'd be lying if I said they compared to actual pork buns but it makes a hearty, satisfying substitute.

Spinach dumplings (3) - Very good. Must order. It was light, satisfying, and large portions without making you feel heavy afterwards.

Service - Nice.

Interior - Very quiet. I don't think I heard music the entire time.

***Cheap, Great Service, Lots of vegetarian options***

For all the veggie lovers out there, this is a highly recommend place. It's dim sum style where you can share the small plates. You will definitely get full and not spend a lot of money! FYI it's cash only!!

THIS PLACE IS SO YUMMY! AND well priced. The place is small and we went in Christmas Day, so there was a 20min wait, not bad overall. We had four dishes between 2 of us and that was plenty (you could get away with 3 dishes even). We had the mock roast pork buns, snow pea dumpling (my favorite, kinda gooey), rice flour roll with Chinese kale, and fried Napa roll. Everything tasted fresh and delicious. I only dinged one star because they forget about one of our items until we reminded them...and I heard 2 other tables around us have the same thing happen. So if you notice one dish seems to be taking longer... speak up! Because otherwise this places is 5 stars all around.

I've been going here since 1998 and it is THE BEST place for an all vegetarian dim sum and entree menu! One of my favorite restaurants in NYC, I hope it stays open forever. The steamed turnip cakes and rice flour rolls with kale are a staple when I die here along with the crispy noodles with spicy tofu. 10 out of 10 !

I asked which dumplings were the best and the waitress informed me that the shrimp dumplings were the most popular.

The dumpling dough was lukewarm and the pieces of veggie "shrimp inside had absolutely no flavor. Essentially, these dumplings were just soggy dough with a hint of oyster sauce. I'm sad to say I wasn't impressed.

I've been going here for longer than I can remember. Best and most affordable vegetarian dim sum in the area, get the pan friend dumplings and the glutinous rice in lotus leaf! Other favorites are their soups (great value), bbq pork, sesame balls, rice flour rolls and watercress dumplings.

Can't wait to be able to eat here again when it's safe. Thanks for sticking around!!

Sorry but...
The worst vegetarian dim sum I have ever had. especially the Fried Raddish Cake. It's terrible.

Way to go NY!

Dim Sum, Vegan style.

The house isn't painted and the carpet is old but the food is Great and the servers are super kind and gentle in spirit.

You don't come here for the ambiance. You come here if you want authentic dim sum gone vegan.

A Vegetarian dim sum place in Chinatown definitely sounds exciting. So we decided to stop over for a quick bite. However, the whole experience was underwhelming.

The ambiance is nothing to write about. The menu is exhaustive. Lot of options to pick from. However, the challenge is that no one bothers to explain what the things on the menu really mean. The servers are little rude and do not answer your questions. They give you a pencil and a sheet on which you can mark what you want. They had 4-5 types of dim sums and we could not figure out which one to pick. So we just went with monk dumplings. These were filled with rice. Who fills dumplings with rice? Completely bland and total waste of money.

We decided to just not try anything else and leave.

However, they do give complimentary green tea for the table which is pretty cool.

So try, but at your own risk!

The best for veg dining in Chinatown. Cozy, tasty food, reasonable prices.
So nice to be able to order anything from the menu!
We're lucky to have such a treasure so close to where we live.

Note: went here December 2013.

This place is amazing. I have a soft spot for dim sum - a Cantonese comfort food. The problem? Not many places serve vegetarian dim sum and if they do, the selection isn't very big. When I heard of this place, I had to go.

The place is smack dab in Chinatown (I think.... we were tourists so that's the impression I got while walking from the subway station). It's fairly easy to find and the place is on the smaller side, but we didn't have an issue getting a table. The decor was simple and nothing noteworthy, but it wasn't dirty either.  They didn't have the rolling carts (no room) but they had a little menu that you can mark what you wanted and give it to your waiter who would bring your selections to your table.

We are strict vegetarians.... but no onion and garlic, so that was the first thing we asked before we began choosing our food. According to our waiter, we could pretty much choose anything on the menu. I was psyched, because this is a pretty rare phenomenon! We ended up deciding upon 7 items for around $25 and it was a lot of food! They were all delicious and though not devoid of grease, it wasn't as greasy as I've seen some places serve their dim sum. We ended up taking back our leftovers and it was enough for dinner.

I would definitely return if I ever find myself in New York again! ...Perhaps it's a good thing that there isn't an all vegetarian dim sum restaurant where I live...

I tried five things and unfortunately I didn't find them delicious. I'm a dim sum lover but this vegetarian dim sum is too different than regular dim sum. It's a good option for vegetarian or vegan people tho.

Good to know: cash only.

I came in not knowing what to expect. I am not familiar with the food, so I ordered "blindly"  what a pleasant surprise. Everything I ordered was very good. Thr pan fried dumplings are very bready...be warned. The spinach dumpling was my least favorite,  but not bad. The Taro dish is really good. The spring roll was hot and fresh. Sticky bun was on point

As a side note, the ladies working here are not all friendly. In fact, they can be down right rude. One lady had discarded food and plates in her hand. She stopped at my table, put the dirty dishes on it and wiped the table
...over my food. Really?  My Taro Balls arrived cold. When I alerted the waitress, she asked, "Oh, you wanted them hot"? In an icy tone with no smile almost suggesting I am bothering her.

Pretty decent for a vegetarian dim sum place. It was my first time eating dim sum too so I was more than excited about trying out everything. My favorites were the rice rolls and the shrimp dumplings. I didn't really enjoy the spinach dumplings but to each their own. The pork buns were alright and the fried wantons were just fried wantons; nothing special. The friends I went with were happy by the end of the meal considering they aren't vegetarians/vegan either and so was I.
The only issue was that we ordered drinks as well on the back of the dim sum menu and they forgot to bring those out so we had to ask for it and it only came out at the end. It wasn't a big deal though considering they were apologetic and it was an honest mistake.
Also, you have to make sure you bring cash, since they don't take card. Otherwise, I will definitely be coming back again to try other items on the menu!

Finally! A dim sum spot that vegetarians can wantonly explore (pun intended) without being limited by the menu or consuming meat that got lost in translation! It was great to finally have the unbridled joy of randomly checking off creatively named items from the dim sum list without worrying about what poor critters made up the contents. Not that there aren't veggie options at other dim sum places but they are few and far between. This was the first place I've been to where the entire menu is vegetarian friendly.

We ordered a soup and 7 items off the dim sum list and it came out to about $35 which was great value. We ordered way more than required but everything looked so good! The servers were really friendly and they make excellent recommendations since a lot of the items have fanciful names that give you no idea as to what they actually are. The 2 best things we orderef actually were the ones recommended by the server. They also bring you a kettle of hot tea as soon as you go in which was a nice touch.

Can't recommend this place enough for vegetarians and even if you aren't one its still good some great food. Only drawback is its cash only but the food is worth every penny.
Very fast service and a huge variety of dim sum. We also shared the rice with vegetables in curry sauce and It was fairly decent. Would definitely go back for great food and reasonable prices.

So we had dim
Sum at Buddha Bodai last week and now I'm
Here. The ambiance is even less inspired, hard to believe but true but the food is outstanding, my Chinese friend recommended this place and he had a point. Delicious authentic plant based dishes. Yum. Who needs to be eating animals if one can have this instead! Unbelievable. So good. Wish they invested a bit of coin in a couple of gallons of paint and a bottle of windex and I'd gladly add a star!
BEST Italian sauce in town. I LOVE the Calamari with extra sauce. I am in heaven at Vincent's.

It pains me to say this, because my family has ties to this neighborhood going back to the 1800s, but Vincent's is a shadow of its former self.

For generations the restaurant has stood as a staple of the community - providing homestyle, red sauce style entrées. This was the place you would go to if you wanted linguini in clam sauce, lasagna, rigatoni in vodka sauce, or other straight forward, Italian dishes.

These days I'm sad to report that the food is pretty average, at best. Frankly, I thought about giving this restaurant two stars, but probably kicked up the score a little bit based on nostalgia. The pasta is a bit soggy and bland for my taste, while the sauce probably tries to overcompensate a bit too much. The resulting dishes felt like some thing you could find at any generic, non-Italian restaurant. There was never a dish that stood out as flavorful or felt like it would provide a reason for someone to specifically seek out Vincent's for a meal. It was so upsetting, because you could feel the history of this restaurant, and so desperately wanted it to be what it once was.

The rigatoni in vodka sauce is good, but not great. I've had better, I've had worse, this was right in the middle. The clam sauce, wants to go-to on the menu, just didn't quite have the same pizzazz or flavor that it used to have. The red sauce was over seasoned albeit freshly made.

The service was a bit slow. I certainly understand that restaurants are struggling with this aspect of their business, but it really wasn't busy enough to take as long as it did.

The ambience itself is what you'd expect, it's still has that classic Lower East Side /Little Italy vibe to it. It's just a shame the meal did not match the mood.

It kills me to have to admit this, it really does. But Vincent's, if it ever was good, is not that good anymore.

I had been here in years past, and always thought of it as a staple of the neighborhood. My friends and I would debate who had the better sauces ... Vincent's or Little Charlies (long since closed). I always loved both but my heart always settled on Vincent's. Well, I have bad news. The food here is sub par. The good news is that the sauce is still top notch. Buy the medium for a nice flavor that's not too hot, or the hot, to switch things up from what you make at home, or what you can buy at a supermarket (please take note ... the "Vincent's" you can get at the supermarket, while good, is not the same Vincent's, this is the only location where you can buy it).

Honestly, just skip the sit-down experience. Perhaps cost cuts to pay rent, or the lockdowns and staff shortages have taken their toll. Whatever the case, I can't in good conscience recommend you do the sit down. Buy the sauce, buy a shirt, take some pictures to show your friends, and skip everything else.

For reference, we had the scungilli with medium sauce, and fried calamari with hot sauce. In both cases, the sauce stole the show, but the scungilli was so chewy it was hard to eat, and the calamari was completely limp. Clearly had not been made fresh, had been sitting out, and they just poured sauce on it. Service was far less than swift. It even took them forever to bring the check, something you'd think they want to do quickly.
We've visited Vincent's every time we come to the city, for over 20 years! Food is amazing! If you are looking for old school, legit Italian food this place is for you!
Not what I expected.My friend recommended this restaurant to me and did not lived up to my expectation.Too much food does not mean is cuality..The pasta with calamari was too spicy.Not coming back..
this pasta changed my pasta pov, and the waiter was amazing! my sister ordered champagne and he forgot came back voided the champagne and then brought her a little bottle.

Disappointed Pizza was trash. Tasted like I ate tomate sauce straight out the can.
Waiter was extremely nice however, service was nice.
Cute location.
Wouldn't recommend drinks here.
Wanted a refreshing drink but all they offered was soda and alcohol. No iced tea at least just sugar or alcohol:/
Menu was very limited, you could grab double the amount of food here somewhere else for WAY LESS.
$120 for two drinks, lobster ravioli, margarita pizza.
Def not worth the trip to crowded little Italy.

Holy Cow!  I grew up here and came to Mulberry with my dad to the old Umbertos Clam House in the 70's and 80's and in the 90's and 2000's frequented some great Italian restaurants on Mulberry.  Last night we were walking the neighborhood and accidentally turned left on Mott off Mulberry and saw Vincent's.  I could not believe the amazing history and all the sports and entertainment personalities that have frequented over two centuries and still do.  We came back for lunch today  and as an old friend used to tell me your first time eating at an Italian restaurant you get the linguini with red clam sauce and if that's good the rest is also good.  So I started with eggplant rollotino and Ceci had the mozzarella and tomato (the bread is light and delicious but you have to ask for olive oil and balsamic).  Outstanding!  She had the cold seafood salad with grilled shrimp and I had of course the linguine and red clam sauce.  Both were awesome .  I had to ask for more bread to sop up the sauce.  Waiter has been here 18 years.  Owner kept everything going and staff paid during COVID!  This is a real gem and you have to know about this place to come here because you won't see it on Mulberry and there is no one outside offering free wine to dine!   If your a tourist from out of state or the country you must try this New York institution.

This place also serves over priced drinks and has horrible food. Staff is horrible. Cleanilness is terrible.

0/10 experience I will definitely never  come back... waste of money
You see the cool signage out front, the food is fantastic, the service is consistent, only complaint is that the food is made to order. So you might wait, but that's the price you pay for fresh

Went to Vincent's during San Gennaro and was looking forward to having Italian food. The service was Terrible and it took forever to get drinks, bread and our entrees. Idk what happened to this place but the quality has taken a big nose dive, the food was bland and served luke warm. Also I'd Like to mention the guy at the door John was smug and obnoxious.

Vincent's came at the recommendation of a Brooklyn-based friend as one of her family's favorite eateries. Situated under the glowing "Little Italy" sign, it's clear from the street that Vincent's is a longtime NY establishment. Boasting over 100 years in business, with free samples of their 3 signature sauces on the table at the entrance, Vincent's is the kitsch, dated Little Italy stereotype: a spinning dessert display of cannoli and cheesecake, walls lined with NY memorabilia and signed head shots, and a festive waitstaff in their matching uniforms. It's got a bit of a diner-y, hole-in-the-wall feel, casual feel. Definitely don't feel obligated to sport your Sunday Best.

So, don't get me wrong - their signature sauces are delicious. They have a sweet, medium, and spicy. I'm a big fan of spice, but not really when it comes to Italian dishes. Unless it's a sausage or something, I'd rather my taste buds focus on the herbs, cheese, and carbs. However, the medium sauce had the perfect amount of kick.

Prices are about what you'd expect for a NY restaurant, if not a little more expensive. I'd say just slightly pricier than an Olive Garden. Unfortunately, I could also compare the taste of the food to an Olive Garden. They do provide fresh, hot bread for the table. It's super yummy - and might have been the highlight. Be sure to ask for oil and vinegar. They have both a traditional balsamic and a spicy vinegar. I was a fan of both.

For my entrée, I splurged on the $25 Shrimp Scampi. The portion was practically perfect, if not a little less than I was hoping for. The shrimp was perfectly cooked, but the sauce was a little runny and also....it was orange. Not sure where that hue came from, but it reminded me of the grease you blot off a slice of pizza. The flavor was good, but not WOW. Especially for $25. My friends ordered the lobster ravioli and substituted the Vodka sauce for their house sweet red sauce. They described their meal as "subpar."

The service wasn't super fantastic. While the staff was nice, we had a few different waiters throughout the night, and we waited ages to get our check and pay for our meal.

Overall, I'm not sure I'd run back here. I'm sure there's better Italian to be had in the city. Vincent's is more of a tourist attraction, and I wasn't particularly impressed with the food. Maybe sticking to a simple pasta and sauce is the trick here.
dislike

Went here last night with a friend and unfortunately was not impressed very much by the service or the food. The restaurant is spacious and pictures of the original restaurant and customers they've served covers the restaurant. They showcase their desserts of cheescake, cake, and other pasteries in display cases. My friend and I sat down and decided on an appetizer of fried calamari and entrees of penne a la vodka and linguine with sausage and meatballs. While waiting for our food a slab of cold bread with butter was brought out. I ate it because I was very hungry and I needef something to soak up the wine and martini that I drank.

The fried calamari came out and it was a translucent white color. Usually fried calamari is brown, not a see through white color. It tasted rubbery and had no flavor at all. The two sauces that they brought out were nothing to sneeze at and were very bland. One was supposedly hot, but it tasted just like the other mild one, so no spice at all.

After about 30 minutes after we received our appetizers our main entrees were brought out. My friends penne a la vodka was full of flavor and you could taste the mix of red pepper and other spices. My food on the other hand had no flavor whatsoever. If it wasn't for the broccoli, which did not come out until 15 minutes after our food, I would have sent it back. The broccoli was the best entree on the table. Full of garlic, pepper, and butter--so good. I added that to my linguine and it made all of the flavors pop. It is sad that I had to add the broccoli to make the linguine taste better. I am hoping that the garlic and spices really soaked in as the linguine, sauce, and meat were very sad and low on flavor.

As far as the service the waiters seemed very bored and not excited to help us at all. There were tons of other Italian restaurant on this street and little Italy, so I think I will go there next time. I suggest the same to you.

I guess it's not fair to give a full blown bad review on a restaurant in these hard times but I would say my experience at Vincent's was nothing more than ok. Expected a little more "wow" factor to some of the dishes I tried. The calamari was a little chewy and my chicken dish said it came with potatoes and I got French fries... was a little disappointed.

Every time I come to New York, I make it a point to visit Vincent's in Little Italy. A family owned and operated restaurant, I always feel like part of the family once I walked through the front doors.

It's very easy to find this place, right next to the Little Italy sign on Mott Street. It's cool to walk around and take a look at all the pictures of the famous Italians that have visited and signed a picture. Mine and my boyfriend's personal favorites was of the cast of The Godfather and Goodfellows. We started off with the Vincent's Special, which is the cappuccino with a little bit of liquor mixed in. So yummy and warming on a cold and snowy day! We also had the garlic bread, chicken fettuccine, and the spaghetti with meat balls. It was so hearty and delicious! You can tell that a lot of love was put into making our meals. My fettuccine has the right amount of sauce, making it creamy and tasty. And who doesn't love garlic bread?

For dessert, we had the cannoli cake. I love cannolis, but this cake was what dreams were made of. So moist and sweet. I can't  wait to come back next year!

The only reason for 4 stars is that the service itself was slow. Other than that, great experience!

Came here during the San Gennaro feast. It was pretty good. I had a half Cesear salad which was still a pretty big salad. They used seeded semolina bread as their croutons. Pizza was good. I posted a picture of the meat lovers pizza. Please note there is not a lot of meat on this pizza. I would
Go back to try something other than the pizza. It was ok just not jumping for joy for it.

This restaurant is over 100 year old and was near our Air BnB. Four friends and I were delighted with our meal. My friend and I enjoyed a pitcher of Sangria. Baskets of bread were passed along with plates of lasagna, eggplant parm and regular spaghetti. One could select mild or hot sauce. I felt like we got a true Italian meal in little Italy. This place was so good we even ordered from Post mates on our last night in the city. Check it out....

I came here for lunch with my Dad. He really had a craving for linguine with white clam.

It has been a few years since I've been to this Vincent's, as I usually opt for Chinese food in this area. I went to the Vincent's in New Hyde Park more recently and it was just OK but really overrated.

This Little Italy location, however, used to have an amazing friend calamari with spicy marinara sauce and it also has a retro sort of charm to it so we gave it another try.

The clams used here are definitely fresh and the pasta was flavorful, but not the best I have ever had or even close. The bread was also nothing special and in a dish with a lot of sauce, bread is important.

I may come back and have the calamari if I'm around anyway, but probably won't go out of my way for this place.

Great food
Love
Yum yum
Whenever we were in Little Italy we always go to Vincent's it's a wonderful place and the most delicious Italian food.

Stopped in here for a nice dinner before seeing a show on a Thursday night. The place was pretty empty, and pretty run down looking, but for being 114 years old, I was willing to let that one slide. For how deserted the restaurant was, the service was pretty slow, but we had time, so I let that one pass as well.

My boyfriend ordered the Little Neck Blue Point Clams for himself, and the House Salad with Balsamic Vinaigrette for us to share. The salad was iceberg lettuce, which I hate, and the dressing was unappetizing. The Little Neck Clams were served like oysters, not steamed, which my boyfriend said was inedible. He choked down all but one, not wanting to waste an almost $9 appetizer. The drinks, a Chianti or my boyfriend and a Cosmopolitan for me (I had to have at least one while I was in NY) were pretty subpar as well for the price.

We then ordered the Fettuccine Alfredo to share, and he ordered a side of meatballs. The Fettuccine Alfredo was the best I have ever had! The sauce consistency was perfect, not too watery or too thick. That's next to impossible to find with Alfredo sauce, almost no one gets it just right. The noodles were the cooked just right, and the size was just under what most fettuccine noodles are, sopraffino! And the flavor... Oh the flavor!! Not too rich or too bland, just the perfect amount of flavor, extremely addictive. I don't know if that was just luck, or that Vincent's has just perfected Fettuccine Alfredo. My boyfriend isn't a fan of Fettuccine Alfredo, but LOVED this one. We devoured every bite. He was also in HEAVEN with his order of meatballs. He said they were close to the best he's ever had as well.

Overall, I'd come back here, if I were ever in NY again, and just order the Fettuccine Alfredo. That was more than worth a repeat meal. But it definitely wasn't at the top of my list for best overall restaurant experience on my trip to NYC.

I've been here twice with my family and loved it both times! Their pizza is amazing but pricey- a staggering $15.95-16.95 for a personal sized pie but worth every bite. They have one of the best pizzas I've ever tasted. The crust and dough have a nice bite and crisp to it. The sauce is delicious and plentiful. The cheese is generous and melty and ooey-gooey. I've tried their cannoli which has a crisp shell that cracks and breaks upon bite. It tastes fresh and pairs well with their cannoli cream which is rich and decadent. My favorite dessert there is the mixed berry tart though. It's layers of raspberries, red berries with cream and a crust. They always give you bread which is hot and crunchy. The service is good and friendly. I always make an extra effort to come here whenever I'm in Little Italy!

I realize recent times have been tough for the restaurant industry. I'm happy to be more forgiving in such times.
I've been coming to Vincent's for years now and have to say was totally disappointed in the reduced portions they now serve, although very good.
My usual-fried shrimp in medium sauce for now $24 looked like an appetizer anywhere else.
I got 8 small shrimp and a tiny piece of bread as my meal!
I've seen Vincent's do a hell of a lot better than that in the past!
The waiter was also inattentive despite the place not being crowded.
Perhaps the only positive note was that my 12 oz Budweiser was $6, which you would pay in a dive bar in NYC.
Since linguine and salad overhead costs are very cheap, you would think they would include that in the price instead of getting a measly "dinner" served on a plate as big as an ashtray!
I think I'm done with Vincent's.

NYC classic ...been eating there since i was 4 years old ...my Dad was born on Mott St , My Godfather had the pork store across the street "Fretta Bros" and my cousin family still has the oldest Bakery down the block ..

My Godmother lived in building where Vincents is ...along with some wonderful men whom im still friends with this day ...

Its a New York legend ...was there last night and best Calamari & Squinguilli in the citt along with the best Oysters on the half shell ..

Prices are more than fair for NYC ...Oysters go for 3 dollar a piece in most places ..Vincents ..19 bucks a dozen ...ya cant beat it ..

And only place that still has good Squinguilli not canned s***...waiters are best , typical nyc guys ...not because they all know me theyll treat you right too ...

A must see for those who have never been and worth the repeat for those who haven't been in a while ...cool & casual place ...great food at great prices and go walk around try ROMA for some dessert up on Mulberry St ...another friend of mine and yours too
Loved it here.  The staff was very friendly and welcoming.  The food was awesome, really good red sauce.  Eggplant rollatini was cooked just perfect.  I would definitely eat here again.
Worst service... Waiter didn't server water, when we ask something , waiter speak rudely in a weird face.

This restaurant might have been good years ago, but now it has gone downhill. They make great sauce, but everything else (including the meats, breads, appetizers) is pretty disappointing. Also, the waiters seem over their jobs. The service was pretty disappointing. There are many other great options in the area. Look elsewhere is my advice. You won't regret not going.

We stumbled upon this gem while walking around NYC. I tasted their sauces that they allow samples of outside and it was delicious. Practically begging me to go in.

The inside is quaint and cozy. I did think it was funny that the music played was classic rock instead of a more mood setting style of music for atmosphere, but I can't complain when I hear Queen. :)

We started with the stuffed artichoke which was delicious. I have never had this before but I will surely order again and I can only hope it has the plethora of flavors this one did. We even used the juice to dip our bread in.

We shared an order of lasagna and a Vincent's salad. The salad was ordinary, but it's a plain salad so there is not much to be expected. It was enough to share, that was for sure. The lasagna was perfect. The noodles al dente, and the sauce was full of bold flavors. You can definitely tell they cook their sauce for hours. I wish I would have brought some back to the room. :)

The service was also great. Very attentive wait staff, never even had to ask for a refill. Perfect ending to a perfect day in Little Italy NYC.

Came to this restaurant after the Yankees game while on vacation with my family and I hate to say this but my experience was terrible!! We were a big party of 10 people but other than us there were only 2 other couples enjoying a meal. The service was okay up until the point where we were waiting over 45 minutes for our food!! Because we were such a big group and we know restaurants like to bring everyone's food out at once, we tried to be understanding. However, out waiter did not come check on us not once during the 45+ minutes that we were waiting for our meals. It was aggravating that the waiter did not even have the decency to check up on us to apologize for the wait or refill out water.

The food FINALLY came out and much to my dismay, it was not worth the wait. While the food was not bad, it was not what I expected from a famous Italian restaurant in Little Italy, NY. We all ate our food and quickly asked for the check, as it was already 12am and we were all exhausted. The waiter again took forever to bring us the check. He took even longer to process our payments. We split the check 4 ways and were waiting 15 minutes for him to come back out with our cards.

Overall, I would not come back here. With so many amazing restaurants all throughout New York, I don't know why anyone would waste their time waiting more than 40 minutes for mediocre tasting food.

You want to find a place that is fun and has great atmosphere come to Vincent's restaurant !! Our waitress was amazing Ranisa was great! The Food delicious just like little Italy! Big screen hanging with family!have to get meatballs!!ssuce gravy was great!
Love this place

Our first time in Little Italy!! Our tour guide told us this was the place to eat. Been there for over 100 years. We weren't that hungry so we shared. I had sangria. Yumminess. It was so so hot and the AC felt great. Bathrooms were clean.
 We had meatballs and an order of cheese ravioli with medium spice sauce. It. Was. Delicious! Reminded me of my grandmother's sauce. Meatballs melted in my mouth. A nice crisp outside and tender inside.
I wish she was alive so I can share all my experiences from NY with her.  Her parents came over from Italy and this experience was so special.
Of course prices are high but you're in NY what do you expect?
Everyone was nice. We weren't in a hurry so didn't pay attention to service being slow or not.
I hope one day I can return!!
-from So. Cal

We stopped in for lunch and were very pleased. The pictures on the wall were impressive and we enjoyed looking at them. The food was delicious! The sauce was unlike any I had ever tasted and the mozzarella was immaculate and melted to perfection. The meal came with bread and butter which was delicious, soft and fresh. We each enjoyed a salad with our meal and the entrees were to die for! My fiancé enjoyed baked ziti and I had a succulent chicken parmesan dish. The price was extremely reasonable. We could not have been more satisfied with the lunch we had in Little Italy. We will definitely recommend this location to others!
Such a great place with really friendly staff. I've been going to little Vincent's on Long Island and this place the food is so much better especially the sauce.

I ate at this restaurant back in 2011, the first time I came to New York City.
Me and my friend excellently strolled into this place craving Italian food and boy did we get it.

It was one of the best places I have ever eaten at and when I came back to New York in 2012, I was craving some good Italian food, however, hurricane Sandy had other options for me. I was not able to visit this restaurant due to the situation that was going on, however, this trip I was!

This place has been around for over 50 years so that's got to say something about it. I highly recommend the spaghetti and meatballs!

Situated in Little Italy this is a small Italian restaurant that was recommended as a must go-to for their sauces. I enjoyed my food but it was standard... nothing really blew me away other than the sauces. I doused everything I ate in sauce! The chicken Parm and Fettucini Alfredo were not bad but didn't really offer anything new or special... after asking for a side of their hot tomato sauce/paste I ate every bit of it.

The service at this place was a perfect 10. I was blown away by the kindness. Very attentive and willing to accommodate special requests (I asked for A LOT of sauce)... would definitely recommend this place if making a stop in little italy. It is not fancy and great for a quick stop!

We went to the feast of San Gennaro last night and had a wonderful time. As tradition has it, we went to Vincent's on Mott street in little Italy line we do every year. I grew up in this neighborhood and have coming o this place for as long as I can remember. I love this place, especially during feast time, lots of people watching and seeing their first experience here is priceless. We had drinks and a some apps. Baked clams, calamari and shrimp combo in medium sauce. OMG that sauce is unbelievable, I would put it on everything, it's the best. Since I work near by I have a feeling I'll be back for lunch this week. I can't get their calamari and sauce out of my head.

Traveling from Boston with family, experience a good dinner nothing to exquisite but it was okay. We had calami and shrimp Combo with biscuits were hard. Chicken parm was okay, just wish the spaghetti was more strained Aggravating! I was expecting a sauces to be a little bit better honestly haven't been here in a while we usually visit Brooklyn for Italian food. But honestly don't think I'll return in the future

The only person at our 9 person table who finished his plate was my brother in law, who's subsisted entirely on nutrisystem meals for the past few months.

The food was bad.  Like, really bad.  My pizza was comparable to the pizza that my niece and nephews made when they were 4 years old.  The pasta dishes were consistently inconsistent, with a sickly sweet overseasoned sauce that seems to be the default for every dish.  My wife ordered vodka sauce on her dish, which was a different color than the dish her brother had.  They ordered the same thing.

Service was bad.  They didn't even refill the water!  It was just gross.  I watched my poor sister in law, who's the newest family member, politely chew with a look of despair in her eyes.   Her eyes were blinking morse code for "help me"

How do you mess up "fresh mozzarella and tomato"?!  I don't know.  Start with hard, half frozen mozzarella cheese.  

I had to sleep on the couch last night, and I didn't even pick the place.

The original Vincent's in little Italy!
This is located in the heart of little Italy and has stayed true to their roots for as long as I have been going!
My favorite part is being able to choose how spicy you wold like to have the sauce!
I like to have the sweet sauce with a side of the medium sauce to spice to my specific palate! Yum!

I highly recommend the backed clams  :)
If you are a lover of seafood\, I recommend the scungili salad!  It is kinda hard to find these days but I love it and have loved it since I was a child.  On this last visit, it did required some salt but it was otherwise prepared perfectly!

My only issues with this venue is that there is only 1 bathroom/sex and the service is kinda shoddy.
BUT if you are looking for good, fresh, home made style Italian...this place cannot be beat (unless you come to my Momma's kitchen!)

Service was terrible.  Older gentleman who seated us was in normal street clothes and I thought he was somehow the manager?  Then he changed into his waiter outfit (vest, tie, etc.) and he served us...OK?  Very slow in between orders.  He kept passing us up for bigger tables and we were never offered more water, drinks, etc.  He kept bypassing us and never gave us our check.  We went to the front and spoke with the owner and I had to request our check so I can pay.  I told him about the terrible service and our waiter did not deserve a tip.  He shrugged his shoulders and said, "That's his problem!"   My jaw dropped, I paid, and stormed out of there!!!!  Never felt so ignored at a restaurant!  One star is too good
This place has been a favorite of mine since I was a little girl,the linguini with shrimp and sweet sauce is one of my favorite meals

When I first came here years ago I would have given 5 stars. 3 now just for the sauce.
But damn. Every year they have just gone down hill.
They used to start
You off with a garlic and basil infused olive oil dip for your warm bread. They would sprinkle parmesan into the oil and it was amazing.
The calamari was a huge serving including the tentacles....
and the shrimp parm was huge and juicy.
Now.... ok the sauce is amazing but they abandoned all the special touches that made this place special.
We won't be going back anytime soon. We can just buy the sauce in stories ..... although I make my own that's almost as good.

Best restaurant. Top of my list
Bread with olive oil.  Linguine and shrimp balls.  I bought 5 jars of sauce to go.

We don't live up there anymore but still go at least once a year

Yes it's tourist bait, and yes there are plenty of other choices for food in Little Italy which are supposedly better, but Vincent's is where I ate the most amazing meatball sub I've ever tasted.

The service was a bit slow, which gave use time to look at all the photos of famous folks who've visited over the years. I particularly enjoyed the photo of Sinatra in the kitchen making pizza!

I'm not saying this place is perfect, far from it. But if you want to eat somewhere stacked in over 100 years of tradition and history, this is the place to go.

Oh, and order the meatball sub. It's phenomenal!
The sauce has a weird smokiness that is not great. Everything is bland and unappealing. A friend told us to try it but wish we hadn't. Super expensive- total waste of money

Best Italian in little Italy, not sure why this place isn't even listen when you search Italian in little Italy.
You people are haters and snobby yelpers. Vincent's is the oldest restaurant in Little Italy and the BEST my family is Italian and we LOVE this place it's the best chicken parm, Alfredo, vodka sauce everything. The best of the best here somehow it has only 3 stars but that's so wrong! This place is number 1!

TERRIBLE. I ordered a shrimp linguini and the shrimp was overcooked. I asked the waiter to change it. Then about 10 minutes later the manager gave our waiter the shrimp but without the linguini. Needless to say I'm still hungry. Instead of giving 1 star which I think is very generous, why not a 0 star? It's no fault of the waiter but the manager neglected the needs of the customer.

Tourist bait.

Stay away from this place.

When i walked in, there was a weird smell. However, everything that we ordered was perfect!

The seafood salad was delicious and had the right amount of garlic! And the seafood was so fresh! Best seafood in little italy hands down! everywhere else is too chewy!

The calamari with linguini is the best! And the manhattan clam chowder was so fresh!

Everyone was pleased!

Chicken Parm with rigatoni and medium sauce. Best I've ever had. Every time I come to the city I make sure to stop by even if I have all my luggage with and they always accommodate. I love this place!

Great food, best Italian we've had in a long time.
I had the linguine & meatball and red sauce & my wife had the linguine & Alfrado sauce. We can't wait to come back!!

I was running errands in Chinatown and met my mom for dinner. She said that Vybes was new and asked if I wanted to try it. I thought, why not.

We had two dishes - walnut shrimp and a veggie dish. With a dessert, it was $75 for two people, which is hella steep for Chinese food. I know walnut shrimp is a typically expensive dish, but it was at least $10 more here than in other similar restaurants like Uncle Lou.

The food was OK. I probably wouldn't spend the money to eat here again, since I can get it better elsewhere in Chinatown. Service was attentive and nice.

Awful. Just awful. We ordered 8 items, and 3 of them were unavailable. It took nearly 40 minutes for all of our food to get to our table. There was no reason for the kitchen to be that slow - the restaurant was empty. If you're looking for old ladies pushing carts, you won't find them here.

Last but not least, the menu lists a 15% discount if you dine between 9am-12pm. Upon paying, we discover that the discount only applies if you pay with cash. The menu didn't specify that detail.

I hate to write bad reviews, but it's been awhile since there's been such a massive gap between what the online reviews seem to suggest and my actual experience. I went with my family for dim sum and something felt wrong from the beginning. The interior pictures you see online ARE NOT the ones you get with dim sum...it feels like you're eating in some half-completed Brooklyn startup office in a bad way.

Now, onto the food. This was truly a terrible dim sum. Food was bland, doughy, and honestly, did not feel fresh at all. We noticed a lot of the food came in from the front door...do they even cook the food at the restaurant?

Lastly, to round it out, service. We didn't even receive all of the dishes we ordered, they constantly forgot we even existed even when we flagged someone down (e.g., tea never refilled, requests for vinegar unfulfilled), and it was impossible to call someone over. I realize the bar for Chinese restaurant service isn't high, and I'm totally okay with that, but the bar here was nonexistent.

Got a chance to eat some classic good dishes from this restaurant -- my favorite was their signature seafood stirfry dish. The sauce was really flavorful and seafood tasted fresh! I also enjoyed the Steamed Fish which was very meaty and soft, though I think it would benefit from a little more seafood soy sauce.

Service was very friendly and quick which was a huge plus and food came out one after the other, hot and fresh. The overall vibe from this place is more upscale and nice, so I'd recommend coming here for special events and gatherings. I hear they will soon be opening up private rooms and an open bar. It'll be the perfect place to host parties and dinners!

I hope to be back soon with a bigger party, and to try their other dimsum and family style dishes. Will update with any new recommendations!

Dropped by this new place in Chinatown (old church) for dimsum.  Hard to find.  Not great signage.  Still new so the restaurant is figuring it out.  Ambiance is as good as it gets especially the special lighting for photography. Dim sum is made to order (like most restaurants the dim sum is not made in house but steamed at the restaurant).   Taste is OK. Service is passable.  This is more of a place where you want to catch up with friends and good environment to chat vs being a place you are there just for the food.

Pricing is the big negative here as it is likely the most expensive dim sum restaurant in the area.  

They do provide the highest quality tea in all of Chinatown.

I was running errands in Chinatown and met my mom for dinner. She said that Vybes was new and asked if I wanted to try it. I thought, why not.

We had two dishes - walnut shrimp and a veggie dish. With a dessert, it was $75 for two people, which is hella steep for Chinese food. I know walnut shrimp is a typically expensive dish, but it was at least $10 more here than in other similar restaurants like Uncle Lou.

The food was OK. I probably wouldn't spend the money to eat here again, since I can get it better elsewhere in Chinatown. Service was attentive and nice.

Food (5/5): Went here with a large group of friends across a few tables. They recommended a set of items for us and we had an amazing experience. The dim sum was unbelievably fresh with my favorites being the shrimp har gow, tofu skin, turnip cake, fried noodles, and short rib. Also good were the fried rice and coconut cake at the end. Amazingly well put together menu. Pricewise it was quite good whereby we paid $30-40 per person for a ton of food.

Service (5/5): Food came out fast and efficient with the service being absolutely top notch. Everyone was super friendly and helpful. They checked up on us frequently and even threw in fish and dessert as complimentary. They set a high bar!

Venue (5/5): From the moment you walk in, you are immediately impressed. You go downstairs with some chandelier decorations above and a nice, upscale V symbol. Then when you turn into the restaurant you're greeted with a beautiful mural of a dragon and a piano player on the stage. A truly upscale and impressive setting.

I recently visited the Vybes 109 and overall, I had a pleasant experience. The restaurant had a welcoming atmosphere and the staff was friendly and attentive. The dim sum selection was quite extensive, with a variety of dumplings, buns, and other small plates to choose from.  The pork buns were especially a standout, with a fluffy, sweet bun and tender chunks of pork inside.

However, it is slightly on the experience side. Despite the price, I would still recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for a tasty dim sum experience. Overall, I would give this restaurant a 4 out of 5-star rating.
Staff was friendly and we were seated quickly. A little on the empty side in the evening which was nice, but also made the atmosphere a little bit quiet. The food was 4/5.

If you're in Chinatown you definitely need to visit! Make sure you request the dim sum menu. Everything was fresh and made to order. Our server ensured that we fully understood the items we ordered and made amazing recommendations. We had the most amazing first time Chinatown experience here and know that you will too. Wish I had more space in my stomach and will be back to order off of the full menu which I am sure does not disappoint. 10/10

Dim Sum | Live Music

I was excited to stumble upon a new establishment, and by new, I mean freshly opened. Upon first glance, Vybes 109 appeared closed, but to my pleasant surprise, a staff member welcomed me in for a sneak peek. Located downstairs, I was presented with a copy of their lunch and dim sum menus. Though they opened only a month prior, they held a soft opening for friends and family with complimentary items to try. I was informed of their grand opening event happening this Friday. The ambiance was peaceful, as I was the only customer there at the time, with only staff present. An exciting feature of this venue is the live music that's offered every Friday through Sunday, a rarity in the area. Their unique decor certainly catches the eye. I can hardly wait to indulge in their foods. After looking at their dim sum menu, I noted unique dishes such as Chao Zhou Style Dumpling, Beauty Red Date Pudding, Steamed Lychee Bun, Mint Coconut Cake, Steamed Curry Chicken Bun, and 3 Color Crystal Bun. The restaurant is open 7 days a week from 8 am to 11 pm according to the menu but this page says a different time.

NEW CANTONESE SPOT ALERT  

Came to NYC from SD for a few days and desperately needed my Chinese food fix.. but the city that never sleeps, seems to sleep now. We tried to go to another spot and they were closed. So we called Vybes to see if they were open at 10:30pm on a Monday, it seemed like they were trying to close but didn't turn us away and stayed open! HOW NICE OF THEM!

The place was underground and very ambient with some great dragon  artwork on the ceiling.

We ordered Xiao Long Bao, shrimp shumai and some veggie lo mein! Alongside the mandatory Jasmine tea that was very fresh. Everything was delicious and tasty! Not to mention they were so kind to us and not even rushing us despite literally staying open just for us.

Highly recommend!

We had good experience here for a birthday party of 9. It was pleasant. The owner dedicated a lot for the restaurant and we can see the devotedness in him. Hope they got more customers after my review.
Foods was good as its price since we were in middle of China town.

Came here to try the dim sum. The foods meh. Not much to say. The service is pretty good. Will try the other things next time. They opened up the 1st floor but never see people inside. The basement is where we had the dim sum.

Don't be fooled by the reviews. Had come here for lunch to try out this relatively recent dimsum / Cantonese restaurant.

We had ordered an assortment of dimsum - including 4 plates of different dumplings (taro and pinenuts, vegetarian steam dumplings, pear-shaped fried dumplings, and tri-assortment of sweet dumplings), and eggplant / pepper with daced fishpaste.

Every dumpling would fail for me. The skin was way too thick and doughy, and the bottom would actually not be fully cooked. They probably didn't get their steaming timing correct - the bottom of each dumpling was raw dough.

The filling to skin proportion is bad. The filling itself is not what you'd expect - seemed like they either bought pre-made dimsum or they skimmed on the ingredients if it was self made.

We also ordered lunch specials - the home style fish filet, sweet and sour pork, and the Singapore chow Mei fun. The fish was not bad, probably the only acceptable dish amongst our orders. The sweet and sour pork was extremely dry and, again, the outer coating was very thick (seems like a recurring theme here). Lasty, the chow mei fun was average - nothing spectacular, acceptable at best.

Service - There were 3 staff members. A middle aged man and woman  and a younger guy. The middle aged couple seemed to be the owners. Majority of our lunch, they were sitting or lounging around. Did not look at our way and we had an empty teapot for a while.

Ambiance - Decor is not bad and looks upscale. Wish the food and service would match the setting though.

Not your typical dim sum joint with carts. They try to make the food fresh and higher quality by being made to order. They have someone playing piano live. I really like the teapot that's clear which automatically tells the waiter when it's empty visually. The shrimp har gow was really food. The turnip cakes were very crispy. I think this place is a little more expensive than usual, but it's probably a combination of inflation and higher quality. If you order a fried fish, they debone it for you! I wish the shrimp fried rice had more than 3 shrimp. Pretty hard to split for a big table.

This is a cool spot at 109 Mulberry street, between Chinatown and Little Italy, the interior is designed black and white , with dominate red color seatings, on the ceiling, is a hand painted giant dragon.  Live music on weekends

The food is amazing here. Love The soup dumplings, pecking duck with caviar is a fancy choice, Vybes vegan, cha siu pork meat. For big party, recommend the lobster, pan fried flounder, and Vybes Five treasures.

This restaurant opened recently, and I enjoyed my time and had a great experience. The decorations were very pretty. Every table had flowers and the ceiling was painted with a dragon. The food was delicious. I had a big party and booked 3 tables. We had soup, shrimp dumplings, roasted pork buns, pork rib with rice rolls, fried tofu, fried rice, beef chow fun, greens, and coconut milk dessert. The servers were very friendly and kept refilling our tea. We all ended up paying about $30 -$40 for a lot of food. I highly recommend this place!

This place was an unusually pricey Chinatown restaurant, and unfortunately the food was not standout and the folks working there could be really pushy. We came here for dinner a few weeks ago and were aggressively sold "the best dim sum in Chinatown" - very bold claim! We had already been planning to come check this place out anyways given the glowing reviews - the whole restaurant was pretty much empty at 5PM on a Friday which was totally not what I expected. The live music they tout did not start until 6, and it's basically one pianist. While the interior is nice(r) than most Chinese restaurants in the area and the space is huge, it felt kind of like a 90s nightclub and didn't seem much like a Chinese banquet hall. The service was pretty lackluster and there was only 1 guy serving, who was unsure of our order, had to come back to check what it was, repeated it back to us correctly but still brought out the wrong item to start and I was too annoyed to ask for a correction. In any case, we got to try the mushroom yi-mein noodles which were good, and the crab soup dumplings and regular soup dumplings which were both reasonably decent. Overall, I wouldn't be back and would trade in a less fancy place for better prices and better food.

Take a look at the menu before you settle in and order. Their average entrees are about $35, and even their beef rice and things like this would cost you $25. The price is just ridiculous in my opinion. I don't think the ambiance is worth this expensive. Go to some other places in Chinatown to get authentic foods with much less price

This is the spot to Visit in NY all the Dim sum is amazing, I tried multiple ones and I must say everything was Phenomenal from the service staff and even Bobby the owner/ Photographer. The vibe is amazing the Ambiance is very nice family place and a great late night spot.
The prices vary from 7.50 up till about 12.50 for dim sum.
Also most of what i have tried was at the 8.50 to 9.50 a plate and we shared 95 for 4 people we had more than what the pics shows I will add more pics later

Hey there foodies, don't skip this one!

We started off with the dumplings and I have to say, they were some of the best I've ever had. The filling was deliciously savory and the wrapper had just the right amount of chewiness.

Our main course was Beef Chow Mein and Orange Chicken. Both dishes were absolutely 100%.

Super clean restaurant with friendly staff. We got the soup dumplings, shrimp toast, bok choy, golden egg seafood fried rice and shu mai and everything was incredible. I live in La and all of the food here is comparable to the infamous San Gabriel Valley area. They have live jazz Friday, Saturday and Sunday's too. Hope that this restaurant thrives in the NYC food scene. The server also served us complimentary sweet potato, taro sago too. Sooo good.

New place, with live jazz music, locate at little Italy.
Place n price look high ends but taste so so, cannot say great, maybe they use expensive ingredients but it didn't bring out the taste.
Needs to give some credits to the chef on the  presentation though.
If you are looking for traditional dim sum, you are in the wrong place, lol.
What a great spot! The chicken and crab soup dumplings are so delicious and I'm eager to try more of their dim sum. I'll definitely be back.

delicious soup dumplings came in with large party and our server Diana was very helpful and helped us with the menu  
the mural on the ceiling was beautiful.
will come back again when visiting
Excellent variety of dim sum and great service. This restaurant had a Pleasant clean environment.

Happened to be around so came here for lunch.  The honey bbq buns were tender. Next time I'll bring friends so we can try more things :)  excellent, friendly service, so don't feel intimidated if yöu never tried dim sum before.

This is a new and dynamic restaurant on Mulberry Street. I highly recommend for cool vybes, great food and live jazz music. The Peking Duck And Caviar is sublime, service is outstanding. We had an excellent evening.

So we're in Chinatown looking for food and it's always a crapshoot. You never know what you're going to get. So we decided to go over to Little Italy instead. Soon as we get to Mott Ave, we get the first aggressive host trying to steer us into his overpriced establishment, even preparing a table while he tried to sucker us-- it's such a turn off for a restaurant especially when you live in New York and you're not some tourist. so we quickly escaped only to run into Vybe 109, a Chinese restaurant set back from the street, where sat a young man with a big smile on his face calmly welcoming us to look at his menu. No pressure. Nice kid. The menu looks great, reasonable prices too, and it looks like they have some "soup dumplings" as my niece called them (Xiao Long Bao (小笼包) which apparently is a thing according to this worldly 18 year-old girl. So we followed the guy into a dark, dingy hallway and down some stairs, a little nervous until we get to this really cute little room with red booths, and a big mural of a dragon on the ceiling. He left us in the hands of a young waiter who had one funny line after another. Very entertaining fellow. Started off with some shrimp spring rolls and shrimp toast, followed by soup dumplings, seafood fried rice, General Tso's chicken, and some chicken and broccoli. All wonderfully cooked, and decent portions for the price. A woman in the back, playing piano on a small Casio gave some nice vibes to the room, and all of the staff were so pleasant and nice. We will definitely be back, good luck to them.
Awesome place with great ambiance. We got pork soup dumpling, pork short rib, and egg drop soup. Loved everything. They had live jazz too, and both performers Lucy & Jack were amazing.

Had dinner at Vybes with three friends tonight.  Food freshness was excellent aesthetics was phenomenal and taste was distinctive.  Price is premium so expect to pay the price tantamount to the quality of the food. We ordered lamb chops garlic crispy chicken jumbo shrimp mayo crispy flounder and beef chow mein. All dishes were meticulously made with care and love and talent of the chefs were evident in its presentation when it came out. We ordered 5 dishes and including tips totaled to $55 per person including already the 20 gratuity.  We were happy with our choice and will come back again soon.
Pretty solid, fast service, good food and a decent location! Def a go to spot for me now

Very sad to have to plant fake reviews-- see Fotos associated with several different reviews, all 5 stars saying essentially the same things. Pros- live music, setting, Diana/service; cons-prices, prices, prices.  I wanted very much to give good rating as one in our group was a friend of the owner.  My share in groups of 11 was $55 for average Ctown dishes. Food:  Good portions, fresh, served appropriately (timing)  change of plates good tea,ample seating. Acid test:. Beef chow fun needed better and more oyster sauce more evenly spread out.  If a restaurant can't prepare good chow fun, it's a good bet the rest will be mediocre. Eg, Peking pork chops overly gloppy.  Other dishes were usual Ctown fare, all so so but most over $35.  Few diners will pay the outrageous prices for average food that you can lget elsewhere for less than half vybe prices.
Incredible service. The soup dumplings are divine. The food is beautifully presented. The jazz music and lights create a relaxing environment and makes everything feel appealing!
The food here is delicious! Came in about an hour before closing and the staff greeted us with much positivity! The service was fast and the ambiance of the place is so nice!

The food was delicious overall. We ordered steak, lamb chops, clams with XO sauce, and hot and sour soup. The hot and sour soup was a bit disappointing but I would 100% come back again for the main dishes. The staff was welcoming and the ambiance was nice. Would definitely recommend.

It's hard to find quality Hong Kong dim sum and seafoods these days. Vybes does not disappoint. My mom, being from HK and a huge seafood connoisseur, and I came for both lunch and dinner on our trip to NY. The dim sum is made to order, so it's fresh and high quality. Pleasantly, I did not detect MSG. We had a stir fried black bean clams as well as a steamed fish on separate occasions. Ingredients were fresh and the cooking was well executed. Service was friendly and attentive. Prices may be a little higher, but you get what you pay for.
Food was good but customer service was ass , lady caught an attitude and was talking mad crazy. Never coming here again.
Excellent congee and turnip cakes! Lotus rice dry tasty with even dried scallops. Your stomach will be happy.
First time going to Chinatown with some family and friends. The staff were amazing and so friendly. The food was amazing and soup dumplings were to die for. I am hoping to go back soon

I'm from Toronto where there's plenty of great dim sum, and Vybes 109 was quite comparable! They offer a wide variety of dim sum, and instead of pushing carts, the dim sum is made after you order, so it arrives fresh and hot. Everything was tasty and well done. The chive dumplings with pork and shrimp were tasty, and the stuffed peppers had a nice zing to them. The pork soup dumplings had lots of juice inside. The pork chow foon was delicious. The atmosphere was clean and modern. A welcome addition to Manhattan Chinatown. Would definitely bring friends next time!

Good food and a good time with live music on the weekends. Great for groups! And service was friendly!
I suggest the Peking duck and pan fried flounder :)

We were visiting NYC and looking for a good dinner place in the area. This is apparently a new restaraunt, and I couldn't recommend it more! The food was outstanding, and the staff was very friendly to tourists like us. Their reccomendations were fantastic, and if they suggest something I would highly recommend ordering it.

We happened to find this restaurant for lunch while visiting Chinatown, and loved the atmosphere, which is very clean and spacious. Our staff was so friendly and warm, especially Evan, our server. We ordered a lot of dim sum, and the food was all incredible and very authentic Chinese food. We highly recommend this amazing Chinese restaurant!!!
Very good food and service. Eric's the man. The soul dumplings are fire! If your looking for quality, this is the place

This place is the best! We came in late on a Monday night and the owners stayed late to cook for us. The food was INCREDIBLE. The soup dumplings and chow menu was our favorites. Cute place and really good food. We will be back!
Their shrimp shumai and pan fried radish cake was delicious! Definitely recommend this place!

I had the shrimp toast and pork spare rib rice rolls. The shrimp toast was crunchy and the shrimp was juicy and succulent. The pork spare ribs were also on par. I definitely would recommend the shrimp toast!
Spacious, great food and staff is really nice -- Diane is a great waitress! Would come again!

Very sad to see this fine authentic Vegan restaurant is now closed. First, of it's kind to offer more than Tofu as the main course.
There you could enjoy many Seitan, Mushroom, Eggplant, Arrowroot. Tempeh as main entrees
great food, and tastey! It was in a good location , and the service was great.

We came to Vanessa's Dumpling House as part of our Lower East Side food tour while in New York. Since it was part of the food tour, our experience was different than the typical one, but we were still able to experience the atmosphere and the delicious dumplings.

The interior of the restaurant is cozy, with only about 6 or 7 medium-sized tables. With all the rave reviews we had read, our expectations were high. We had the chance to sample the pork dumplings, which arrived piping hot. They had a lot of flavor, although I must admit I expected to be a bit more impressed.

I'd like to come back here to try different types of dumplings they have to offer so I can get the full experience

I had no clue they had this sesame pancake sandwich. ITS AMAZING! You have to get this. The dumplings are solid and cheap but wow this blew my mind. It comes out relatively quick but there can be a wait. So obsessed with this sandwich with the pork was incredibly tasty.

Cash only
Some seating

It is a largely known dumpling chain and made more aware to tourists by reviews. It became overrated and a known tourist spot but still have somewhat decent offerings.

I took my friend here as she really wanted dumplings and I figure since most tourists and non-Asians customers come here, she can try the dumplings while ordering in English without any issues.

The dumplings are smaller and more doughier... not as crisp or juicy. The hot sauce Sriracha is more watered down (Sriracha is more expensive so I expected most places use other brands) but it was watered down liquid hot sauced. Quality did changed from the times when it was a small hole in wall before getting blown up. Again, I only took her here since the staff can understand English and this quick eatery can satisfy her dumpling crave.

Cash only. We came on a Friday night and it was busier than usual. We got the chive and pork dumplings, Dan Dan mien, and plain sesame pancake. The dumplings were good, had a nice amount of filling, and a nice crisp from the pan frying. Dan dan mien were good and flavorful. The sesame pancake was good, but I would get a filling with it next time.

There are a few large tables, but it's not a sit down restaurant so most people sit and leave quickly. There is a bathroom in the back. They are usually quick, but there was a bit of wait this time.

1/1 Ambience; 2/2 Food; 1/1 Service; 1/1 Value

Some friends and I started our Chinatown food tour at Vanessa's, a modest and casual eatery with limited seating serving up amazing dumplings. The restaurant is clean and really busy being so popular. The service is really quick and efficient. The kitchen is open, so you can see the dumplings being prepared by hand in front of you.

I got the pan fried chicken dumpling with the chili oil and scallions. I thought these were some of the best dumplings I've ever had-- fresh, juicy, and savory filling wrapped in a thin and slightly crispy wrapper. The chili oil and scallions were not spicy, but amplified the umami deliciousness of the meal. I devoured mine in minutes!

Although the dumplings are a bit on the pricier side relative to the many other dumpling shops nearby, I think the price is justified given the high quality! I would highly recommend and will definitely be coming back!

OMG SO GOOD. I'm coming back here as soon as possible. It was amazing food for the price. Only reason I knocked it was because we were continually harassed while eating by people asking for money and food in the restaurant.

Petition to rename it to Vanessa's Sesame Pancake House bc thats what really did it for me

*Cash only or maybe card over $15 according to fellow Yelpers

Pork Sesame Pancake Sandwich with Pork ~$5 9.5/10
-sesame, crunchy pancake with a delicious drip of oil sandwiching juicy, fatty pieces of pork with pickled carrots and cilantro tricking u that this is healthy serving of fresh veggies
-look at the pic and u can hear the crunch of the top layer of the pancake and feel the softness of the lower, breadier layer
-vinegar avail on table and drizzle some of that on it for a switch up of a tarter, more acidic bite
-YUM like the perfect affordable lunch/snack break

Chive and Pork Pan Fried Dumplings ~$5.50 for 8 pcs 7/10
-ahhh, I expected mind blowing, flavor exploding dumplings but these were just some dumplings BUT really bang for your buck dumplings
-it was okay, it was good!! as good as dumplings could get but just expected more
-the pan fry and squirt bottle of vinegar on the table really zhoosh'd it up

Came here for the dumplings, staying for the sesame pancake sammys. Maybe I'm just hard to be impressed by dumplings bc I've never met a dumpling I don't like. Would definitely dumpling again, but nothing worth reporting back on (for the last time, that sesame sammy tho!!!)

For a no-frills dumpling spot in the city, this is your place! Everything is consistently delicious and freshly made! On Friday, I visited for lunch and was lucky enough to find a seat as seating is limited. I had the assorted steam dumplings of vegetables, chicken, pork, and seafood. They are all equally good! The passionfruit green tea with lychee is the best! Also, the scallion pancakes are always worth ordering; I love the pork ones! All in all, Vanessa's is a delicious place to go if you're in the mood for great Chinese food at reasonable prices!

Went here before and remember it being so good, this batch I had this time was alright. Got the chicken dumplings. They didn't really do it for me this time, but they have so many options feel like you def need to come multiple times or order diff types to know what's good

Great dumpling place. I went there for the first time and absolutely loved it.
