That and the service constantly reaching over and around people at intermittent moments to pick up things it was a little strange and also an interruption. It would have been better timed had they done it all at once instead of piecemeal at the table.

Drinks came quickly enough and they have a few of their own custom drinks. The Vestry looked good, but I was driving so none for me. The lady serving wine didn't even bother telling me what it was, only asked red or white, which I wish a little more effort to instruct would have been informative.

The bread was good, although the butter was a little weird, not sure what kind of spices that made it sort of dark and mustard seed patterned. We had a pre fixe menu since we had 11 people. I went with choices that I would not normally make myself or could find it other restaurants. Which is why I didn't get sushi like dishes for the most part, those are safer but easier to get at other spots.

Maitake mushrooms with barley had a wonderful consomme and I wish there was a better balance of mushrooms because it felt like it was mostly barley and squash. Pretty good size serving. My colleagues shated their dishes, too, I had a bite of the big eye tuna which was a good tartare with sesame cracker, and the bite of chu toro was solid but not really flashy and something I felt like I could get elsewhere. Wish they didn't use tuna since I feel like that is endangered.

For my second course I chose the sushi rice which I had heard so much about, it was brilliant, for the first two bites. Then it was simply overwhelming and a lot of sour and acidic flavor, which overwhelmed in the middle after the second bite all through to the end. Almost tasted like sour mayo at the end. This dish would be much better with a much smaller quantity (just three bites would be good) or less acidity which would then build to the total acidity at the end instead of after two bites and going max throughout. I also had a bite of the hamachi rose which was wonderfully balanced between the pear and the fish, probably one of the best dishes of the night.

For the main course I had the cod which was cooked really well, super flaky, but almost no other flavor to it which was weird. At the same time I saw the waygu beef was way too overcooked so I guess I'm glad I went with the bland cod. Some people even left multiple pieces on their plate of the waygu. I think the coriander sauce was something I just didn't enjoy on the cod, but I'm also not a fan of cilantro.

For dessert I had the orange, which had a satsuma orange and blood orange, but was far too sour to enjoy more than one bite of the panna cotta. I'd expected something creamier and smoother, sweeter really.

Overall found many of the dishes underwhelming or overwhelming, not really well balanced or improperly portioned. To some extent I had expected to have really small dishes given that it was French inspired, so I did walk out full which was a good thing, but it was a difficult meal to enjoy. They did give everyone a small box of truffles to take home.

Arguably the best mushroom risotto I've tasted. The menu is mostly seafood but they do offer some delicious cuts of meat. My partner tried the wagyu, and made us think of coming back for the short ribs. The ambiance is cool, the drinks are delicious and clever, and the place itself is modern with fun touches like the fur on the chairs. Definitely will go back for the tasting menu!

This is a Michelin star restaurant and it had the service and food quality to prove it.

The complimentary coat check was essential for the winter and the chairs had a cozy fuzzy throw over them. The service was top notch. They even folded my napkin when I stepped out and cleaned off our table after every course.

We went during restaurant week and got a round of apps, mains, and dessert. The risotto was delicious but the scallops were really phenomenal. The Waygu beef was exceptional and the flavors surrounding it paired nicely. The local cod fish was very good but had an interesting flavor that's not for everyone. The cheesecake dessert was so fun and more gimmicky than I expected from this restaurant but it tasted delicious! The cheesecake was very rich and it was paired with a mouse shaped honey crisp apple. The chocolate mousse with passion fruit was my favorite. Even the chocolate decorative piece was decadent.

TLDR: great atmosphere, delicious food and cocktails, but service was slow

Honestly, I came here because of the cute cheesecake LOL

Between me and my partner, we shared the nori chips, wagyu tartare, tuna tartare, hamachi crudo, sushi rice, risotto, salmon, as well as the cheesecake. Everything was delicious. Our favorites were the tuna tartare, the sushi rice, and the risotto. We were expecting the tuna tartare to be served on brioche toast but it was instead served on a crisp sesame cracker. It was great and tasted more or less like a fancy spicy mayo tuna. Risotto was great as well; felt like a hug on a chilly day. My absolute favorite was the sushi rice. I was reluctant to order something called "sushi rice" but my friends who have been before insisted. Truly one of the better bites I've had this year.

My least favorite was the cheesecake. I thought the texture was smooth and creamy, almost like eating room temperature butter. I thought that eating the cheesecake the apple compote and hazelnut mouse was great, but I needed like 5 mice. The acidity was great.

The restaurant itself looked smart and felt premium but the vibe was relaxed and chill. The one qualm I had with the restaurant was the pace of service. It was quite slow; took us a while to get seated even with a reservation and then it took us about 25 mins for us to get our check after we were served our petit fours.

Overall, one of my new favorite restaurants but I wouldn't get that cheesecake again!

The small bites here are just the best!

The complementary bread came with such a delicious seaweed butter and was an excellent appetizer. As for dinner, we opted for small bites and plates.

- nori chips: our favorite of the night! I love the crunch of the seaweed chip and flying fish roe has such a contrasting texture that combines in a nori wrap so well.

- wagyu tartare: this unassuming dish was also so delicious! It was small, fresh, had a nice delicate crunch from the shell and fresh wagyu stuffed inside.

- tuna toast: the tuna was great! brioche was also so soft. not the highlight of the night though, but still really good

- hamachi crudo: I really was not a huge fan of the kalamansi sauce that paired with the crudo, which also tasted pretty average (nothing special).

Also, to note, the service here is pretty slow. It took us a while to even get water and our menu after we first got seated.

I can definitely confirm with the fact that their hostess is absolutely terrible, rude, and entitled. I worked at several hotel businesses and F&B establishments for variety of positions including front of house, back of house and management positions. I'm beyond curious of how and why she still works here. You can find other guest complaints on here too. No doubt all these posts are for her. First impression is everything when it comes to hospitality. She is unfit for this job.

Talk about fine dining. Came for restaurant week and it was a lovely experience! They started us off with sourdough bread and the most phenomenal butter. For appetizers, we ordered sushi rice and grilled calamari - sushi rice was the way to go. For the entree, I ordered the young chicken which was so fresh and tender but the purée was easily the best part. My friend ordered the Atlantic salmon which was average/nothing special. The cheesecake was cute and had a pudding-like texture.

There was a bit of a wait and we got seated ~15 minutes after our reservation time but the service thereafter was great. Overall it was a nice experience with fresh, aesthetically plated food.

One of the best meals I have had in a while. I came here with my brother and family for my brother's birthday and we were very impressed. Excellent service, excellent food, and a great location.

We started with Crisp Softshell Crab, shigoku oysters, sushi rice, chi Chu Toro, Nori chips with salmon and tobiko. All were super fresh and tasty. We also had kale salad and mushroom soup. My brother wanted to try everything. As the main dishes, we had salmon, black cod and organic chicken.

I would highly recommend this restaurant. Not only was the food so fresh and well presented, the service was also great. I also loved that this isn't your typical restaurant. It brought something different to the table.

For every 100th Yelp review that I write, I usually talk about someplace special, whether a noteworthy landmark or a Michelin-starred restaurant. So, for my 8900th review, I'll recount my experience at Vestry, a stylish one Michelin-starred restaurant in SoHo.

Commendably, Vestry opened during Covid and looks very ambitious, whether a large indoor dining room or exquisite, even palatial-looking outdoor booths when I stopped by. The menu has a lot of Japanese and seafood influences which were obvious from the start.

Confusingly, the first course and the amuse-bouches came all at once. Included in these were the tuna tartare (delicious) and the oyster dip (absolutely indulgent), but I completely missed the fact that some exquisite-looking chips were to be used with the oyster dip, which I shamelessly slurped. This was super enjoyable, albeit an overwhelming amount of umami upfront that would have surely been tempered with the chips.

As for the actual first course, this was a platter of thinly shaved Japanese scallops with kalamansi and sea grapes. Very quickly devoured, but still delightful nonetheless. Enough scallop flavor to be recognizable, but not so much to be "fishy" thanks to the accoutrements.

The second course, the wagyu beef with potato puree and miso mustard, was also savory and indulgent. Although petite in size (this was pricey wagyu, after all), the beef melted in my mouth in such a sinful way, packing a punch far greater than its physical stature. Very satisfying.

Finally, a serving of chocolate buche de Noel struck just the right note for the holiday period in which I stopped by. A large portion and simply bursting with moderate sweetness and a medley of textures, whether the chocolate cake or the crème filling.

At $125 for three courses, fairly reasonably priced given the special holiday menu and the choices on offer. It was ultimately a quick experience (not, say, a drawn-out, two or three hour-long affair) and the pace of service was very rushed, like at the beginning where I had several plates on my table at once. Still, for the quality of the food, I'm willing to bump what would otherwise be a 4.25 or 4.5 star review up to 5.

I visited Vestry recently and while the entrées were good, the appetizers left me disappointed. Here are 4 things that stood out to me:

1. Good entrées: The Big Eye Tuna and Scallops that we ordered for our entrées were quite good. The seafood was cooked perfectly and the flavors were balanced. I could tell that the chef put a lot of care into preparing these dishes.

2. Disappointing appetizers: Unfortunately, the Nori Tempura with spicy salmon and tobiko and the Shiitake Handroll with nishiki rice and wasabi leaf that we ordered for our appetizers left a lot to be desired. The tempura was not crispy enough and the salmon lacked flavor, while the handroll was a bit bland.

3. Average cocktail: I also had the Smoke & Fire cocktail, which was okay and particularly memorable presentation. It had a nice smoky flavor but was a bit too sweet and arrived after an hour after we ordered.                                                              

4. We ordered the Guanaja Chocolate with passionfruit and cacao nibs for dessert, and it was definitely the highlight of the meal. The chocolate was rich and flavorful, and the passionfruit added a nice tangy note.

Overall, while the entrées were good, I was disappointed by the appetizers. The service was quite slow, and the atmosphere was a bit underwhelming as well. We may return to give the restaurant another chance.

The food was okay but the vibe killed it for me. The managers are awful. I overheard one of them anxious, complaining and belittling the staff. I worked in the industry through college and it is awful to still see this type of behavior post covid.

Went to try Vestry for the Restaurant Week menu.

Interior was very nice and had a great atmosphere. Staff was super attentive and friendly.

We started off with bread and butter. I believe it was chocolate butter, which was interesting.

For the appetizer, I got the glazed pork belly. It was tasty and the sauce went well with it. Not dry at all and not overly fatty. (5/5)

I got the supplemented Wagyu upgrade for the entree. It was perfect. Very tender meat with good additions like onions and mashed potato. The sauce complemented the meat very well. Only complaint would be the portion size given the price ($60 with an extra $40 supplement). (4/5)

Dessert was an adorably designed cheese cake with an applesauce mouse. The texture was closer to a thick paste/cream rather than cheese cake. It tasted different from a regular cheesecake with a slightly medicinal aftertaste. (4/5)

Vestry is the Michelin-starred restaurant in the Dominick Hotel. While some of the dishes are quite good and very creative, on the whole the experience is a bit of a letdown. The service is just ok. The cocktails do not meet expectations and some of the food arrived cold. While the chef is good, poor management will be hard to make it a long term winner.

Another 1 star Michelin restaurant from my bucket list.  Lucky today is restaurant week. I can come down and try it out.  Food is good. Calamari is super crispy.  Service is excellent. The corn soup tastes so sweet. Pork belly is a little too fatty for me today. The tomatoes salad is very refreshing.   The wagyu steak is good.  Salmon with seaweed is a little bit too salty and doesn't blend well.  The chicken is so soft.   The cheesecake is phenomenon.  Peach is good too.  Overall I give it a full score

The food was amazing! I traveled to NYC for my birthday, and Vestry was my "splurge" dinner. It was worth every penny! Especially the Corn Soup with Lump Crab beignets. The drinks were delicious as well. I received a drink, called "on the road", or "off the road". It's no longer on their menu, but it was the best drink I've ever had.

My career is is culinary and hospitality, and this restaurant checked all my boxes. Arriving, the host was polite and very informative. My server seemed a little check out, but it didn't not diminish my experience. ALL servers and from what I assumed were managers cleaned and cleared the table. They all re-filled our waters and brought out our food and drinks!

Absolute must try if in the New York area!

Vestry is one of my more disappointing Michelin starred dining in NYC. Prior to dining here, I was super excited given the food looked delicious and it was mostly seafood which is one of my favorite things to eat.

I had dinner here with a few girlfriends and while all the food looked aesthetically beautiful, the flavor fell short. My favorite items of the night was the complementary bread and butter, the sushi rice, and the wagyu. The rest were pretty forgettable.

I was most excited for the Chutoro as it's one of my favorite tuna cuts but the flavor of the Chutoro didn't shine at all.. all I tasted was the grassy veggie it was in. The Kampachi Crudo was bland - unsure how to describe this but the sauce it was in was pretty tasty but the two just didn't work well together; it felt like two different things. For the mains, the salmon and the filefish was good, cooked well but I woke up the next day not remembering how it even tasted. Unfortunately, the subtle flavor of these dishes didn't make a lasting impression.

Overall, the food is pretty average but with a pretty big price tag. I most likely won't return but I have to say service was good.

Great service
Beautiful food
Loved the asparagus risotto with eel
Bronzino cooked perfectly
Great cocktails

Some of my least favorite food words are "New American", especially when they're followed by "Michelin-starred". They conjure up shudder-some images of over-priced, under-portioned, boring, bland, uninteresting Western dishes that "borrow" elements from much more flavorful cuisines, appropriate the sh*t out of them, then get accolades for them.

But Vestry decided to turn their cheesecake desert into a mouse with a slice of cheese, and I saw a photo, noted they were an a la carte restaurant, and thought, "What the hey? At least I won't be forced into a $200+ tasting menu of boring dishes only white people who've never been to Taiwan think are creative."

So one Tuesday night, we appeared. And wouldn't you know it? Vestry exceeded my crater-low expectations for New American fine dining. In fact, it scooped up those expectations and flew them up, up in the air like Superman. And now I might actually have to like this type of food.

The Kampachi Crudo was chef's kiss and generously portioned. The Wagyu Beef melted in my mouth. The Nova Scotia Halibut was the only entree with an issue, in that the flavors and textures were perfect--but the fish was cold. Like it had been sitting out for too long. Whomp, whomp.

On to dessert: The Homemade Cheesecake with a mouse was the creamy, adorable, glorious creation I hoped it would be. I wanted five more of it. Not to be outdone, the Chocolate Tart brought all the other flavors of the dessert world to our table, including tart passionfruit, bitter cacao nibs, and pungent chocolate.

But here's where Vestry really stood out. The phenomenal service. One person was gluten-free, and they went above and beyond to accommodate her. Including bringing her gluten-free bread and butter (the regular butter has soy sauce in it), so she could eat with us. When they learned it was my birthday, they brought a third dessert on the house: Caramelized Pineapple with meringue. By contrast, the two envious French men sitting next to us did not get a complimentary dessert despite also celebrating a birthday. And just in general, our server was a hoot, and there was much love going around.

Drinky drink-wise, The Parasol is perfect for lightweights, while the Laugh Now, Cry Later and Bang Bang were the strongest drinks on the menu and perfect for my work-stressed head.

We had high expectations for this restaurant, but we're quite disappointed.the dishes  were over ambitious with too many flavor combinations.  The specialty bread choices were mushy and uninspired, ask for the plain bread.  It will take a while for the delivery but worth the wait.  It seemed every waiter on the floor had been there less than a week and still was in training.  Over all is was difficult to figure out how they achieved a Michelin mention.

I would give this place a 4/5. A few dishes largely exceeded my expectation. My bf and I didn't order any large plate, just a bunch of bites and small plates and we felt so full.
Tuna toast was amazing. The images online definitely underplay the taste. The bread smells so good and went so well with the tuna. Sushi rice was a must have. Nori chips were as good as it could be. Chu Toro was a disappointment. It's fresh but the radish kinda ruined the raw fish flavor. Oyster was ok but nothing special.
I have to complain about the service. They started taking away the plates while I was eating. I REALLY dislike that cuz I feel it's a distraction.

Came here on a Tuesday night and the place wasn't too busy. The ambiance is nice and modern, and we were seated quickly.

The complementary bread was amazing and a generous amount for the three of us. As many other reviews mention, the flavored butter is also very tasty.

We started with two of the bites, the big eye tuna and the nori chips. These were both delicious, and the big eye tuna was on a very cute fish-shaped crisp.

We also shared some small plates and the cod:
Tuna Toast - this was one of our favorites! The pieces of toast are flavorful and the tuna comes next to the toast like a spread.
Crudo - First of all, I'm forgetting the full name of the dish since it isn't on their online menu, but this dish was light, citrusy and tasty! I personally love anything citrus-y and it had a significant lemony zing to it:)
Cod - The cod was good, but very rich. A couple bites and we felt full! It also came with a puree on the side which was light and complemented the fish really well.

Cheesecake - I had seen so many pictures of the cute cheesecake with a "mouse" on the side, so we had to try it for ourselves. It didn't disappoint, and the apple on the side paired really well with this unique dessert!

Overall, we had a great experience. The service did take a bit longer like other reviews mention, but not very noticably for us. This wasn't an issue too given there were several courses and we weren't in any rush. Was hoping the maitake mushroom would be on the menu as it seems to be a favorite, but I'll just have to come back for it next time!

The food at Vestry was *okay*. I feel like I sadly lost the luck of the draw at our table. Of the four of us, we got salmon, gnocchi, sea bass, and the black cod (my dish)--I think the black cod was the worst of the lot as it was kind of bland.

However, not all was lost! The prawns and gnocchi was super yummy and the sea bass was pretty fantastic as well.

The drinks were also pretty good. They seemed like a decent size, they were appropriately mixed (no diluted drinks here), and for the wine that I ordered, the server seemed well versed and knowledgeable of wine (which I was pretty impressed by).

However, our server was a bit short with us. I'm not sure if it's because we were among the younger clientele, but there was no banter or charm--it was basically just "what would you like to eat" and then "here's your check".

The decor was cozy and well thought out if not a bit kitschy.

I'd rank this among the "wouldn't recommend but I'd go if someone asked me to" camp.

Amazing ambiance.. perfect for a date night out. I had this place on my radar for a while and went to try it out with a friend. It did not disappoint except for the feeling that the portions should have been slightly bigger for the price tag. My experience seem to feel more like a tasting than a dinner. Regardless, the service and options were great. The sautéed foie gras was excellent and the duck breast at medium temp was perfect. The salmon ( not a big salmon guy ) was cooked well. I unfortunately did not take a photos as it would have easily brought attention to my table which I didn't want. The waiters were very accommodating. Definitely a must try ...

We came here for the anniversary. The atmosphere was very romantic and the decoration looked modern. We got sushi rice, which was recommended by many other reviewers, and I would say it did live up to our expectations. We also got wagyu beef and fish dish (i forgot which one), both were nice, and ofc small portion. We finished with the famous homemade cheesecake, which in my opinion, was not as delicious. The cheesecake was too bland and a bit too sweet for my liking. However, it looked really cute.

Vestry need more training on service, three different people asked me what to drink, but nobody filled water for our table.
Food was NOT ok, I had diarrhea right after the dinner. Disappointed experience, I didn't know how it could be Michelin star restaurant

They forgot to give us our food on time, it came cold and did not taste very good. The cheesecake looks cool but tastes like chemicals.
We will not be dinning there again.
Very disappointed!

The food was horrendous and made everyone in my party sick. Not too mention the service was awful and they forgot most of our items. We charged it to the room and we did not tip because we did not receive any service and checking out right now we noticed they added a $100 tip.

How in the world did they receive a Michelin star?

Service was awful.

Food disgusting.

And just a awful experience.

Would absolutely NOT recommend. 0/10 and that's generous.

There was a group of 6 of us here for dinner mid week and half of us liked the food and the other half really didn't at all, so that averaged out to 3 stars.

The great
- all aspects of the service was fantastic
- they usually have a nice outdoor seating area
-The cocktails and wine were excellent.
-The tuna toast was delicious and the best thing we ordered
- bread and butter service

The good:
-wagyu and risotto were both good

The ok:
-sushi rice
-big eye tuna
- hamachi crudo

The wouldn't recommend
-chu toro, nori chips, and chilled oysters (all were little fishy)

The desserts:
- homemade cheesecake was surprisingly very good, it looked like a cute piece of Swiss cheese and was very flavorful
- Chocolate tarte - also good flavors, would recommend
- Caramelized Pineapple - not my favorite

Overall, it was a relatively expensive meal for the amount of food we ordered, we certainly weren't full.  I'm not sure if we'd come back unless someone really wanted to check it out

Came here with a few friends on a Friday evening for dinner and drinks. I really enjoyed the atmosphere and food presentation especially the pictured cheesecake in the shape of cheese. The service was outstanding as we never had to wait long for our drinks or water to get refilled. Everything tasted great, can't wait to come back to try other dishes on the menu.

What? Michelin Star 1? No way....

We paid 200 bucks for this meal. Guess what's the best dish? The complimentary bread.... How sarcastic

Big no no: mushroom (too salty), chu toro (too fishy), dessert

Ok: tuna toast, cod

Service is also bad... not gonna come back

I saw this restaurant listed as part of this year's Michelin list and it was on my bucket list of places to try. After doing my research and reading reviews and they were known for their seafood.

The place is very chic and modern. Upon check in, I was asked to show ID and proof of vaccination. If you're eating outdoors they don't require proof of vaccination. I had my coat checked. I was escorted to my table with a booth and stressed that I was expecting so everything had to be cooked.

The server we had was accommodating, knowledgeable and generous especially in my condition. My friend ordered the dirty martini which he loved. I ordered the Sugar Magnolia mocktail and it was so good I had to hold back so I don't break my wallet.

The complementary bread was fresh and umami butter makes the starter unique.

We ordered two appetizers. One of them was on the michelin list.

1) Shitake Handroll  - this Michelin one biter is a must have and perfect start to the dining experience.

2) Maitake Mushroom - our server highly recommended this dish and we eventually caved in and did not regret it.

3) For the main course we both ordered the Atlantic Salmon. The salmon is usually made medium rare but I have to have mines well done.  The salmon was really good I didn't enjoy the kombu but that could be due to my ever changing taste buds in my situation. I loved the butternut squash soup.  I would definitely tried to salmon again as it should have served.

4) For dessert I was torn between the Coconut Tapioca and the Naval Orange. I went with ny gut and got the Coconut Tapioca and the  server surprised me with the Naval Orange dessert on the house. Out of the two dishes the coconut Tapioca was my favorite.

I would definitely return just to have another meal and try their cocktails or two. Loved the dining experience.

Everything was amazing! The food was spectacular!! Definitely somewhere I will be frequenting when I am in NY! The staff were all attentive from the moment we entered the restaurant to the moment we left! Phenomenal service!  and   dessert could not have been any better! Will always be a stop when I am passing through even for a cocktail!

Food - 4
Service - 5
Ambiance - 5
Price - 4

I feel like I should be rating 5's all across because it's a Michelin-starred restaurant but, I'm just going to keep it honest. The portions are small. Which kind of allows you to get one thing from each of the menu sections. Great idea! My bartender recommended the Nori Chips, Hamachi Crudo and Wagyu beef cheek, and Cheesecake for dessert.

Food - I opted for Wagyu, and it came with a loaf of delicious bread. Again, the portions are small, so I eat the entire loaf.  The Wagyu came in two pieces,  one piece was grilled and another braised. It was freaking amazing. The mushroom miso mustard and potatoes puree paired perfectly. Also, they have a crazy drink selection from wine, spirits to great local beers from Other Half. There are plenty of options for everyone.

Service - Everything that you would expect from a high-end restaurant and more. Prompt, polite, and professional are things I look for in a server, and from the moment you walk in until leaving, this is what you experience.  

Ambiance - You can hear and feel the buzz in the air. It is cozy and modern but not stuffy and touty. Like anything during the pandemic, you want to make sure you have a reservation.

Price - To me isn't a big deal when you're hoping to experience amazing food. However, portion size does matter. The food here is undoubtedly delicious, but I would have liked a larger portion.

Finally, I will be back to experience more items from the menu. The Vestry didn't disappoint.  You should check them out if you're planning a night out.

Went for restaurant week on a Monday night and loved the place! The dim lighting, furniture, dinnerware choices were really beautiful. The waiters were very attentive and kind!

Started off with free bread with this amazing butter! - 10/10 the bread was so good and hot! We ordered another bread later because it was too good

Grilled Calamari (homemade pasta) - 10/10
The portion size was so big for the first dish. The noodle texture was so good and fresh. The calamari was so tender, almost the same texture as the pasta.

sushi rice - 10/10
My friend ordered this and it was also just as good. The rice was really good quality and cooked well. Like it the grain was so fine and was very light

Atlantic Salmon - 10/10
I got it medium well and it was so tender and the skin was so crispy!! They poured this green sauce that was amazing with the salmon. The wakame and wood ear mushroom(?) was really well seasoned and complimented the salmon nicely.

Young chicken - 10/10
I had a couple of bites of my friends and the chicken was sooo crispy on the outside and so tender. The sauce was alsooo delicious. The sauce was so good- creamy but not heavy

Cheesecake !! - 9.5/10
Its soooo cute !  i love it :) but it was so good like it truly tasted like cheese but not in a heavy overwhelming cheese flavor but very light and airy. Almost like a light cheesy mousse. The mouse was a sticky rice(?) I really liked it with the peanuts and it complimented the cheesecake well as none of the flavors were overwhelming. I did wish there was some type of crust for that crunchy texture with the airy cheesecake!

(Not pictured) coconut tapioca
This was so good as well! The coconut was rich and the texture was really good. It had fresh strawberries and was so good !

We were so full and happy with our meal ! it's definitely worth going !!

I had high hopes coming here, especially because this restaurant has a Michelin star. It was a let down. Based on the Michelin review, I was expecting a quieter elegant atmosphere; however, it the atmosphere is bar-like. The restaurant feels very transient, which makes sense because it is located within a hotel. It felt impersonal and unfriendly. Certain dishes, such as the Wagyu beef were outstanding, while all others were very good or just OK. Overall, I think this restaurant is trying to hard and lacks identity. I wouldn't venture here for a special occasion.

Amazing dinning environment, the food was okay. We had restaurant week menu, it included some signature dishes from the restaurant. Most if the dishes are delicious, but the desserts was terrible, cheeses foam cake are taste wired, it taste very oil. The other one is a pudding with tapioca and red berry sauce on the tap... also not taste good.

However, the cocktails options are great, very recommend have some drink with small bite food.

I was ecstatic to find out that this Michelin establishment was participating in NYC restaurant week. Taking from the prix fixe menu, every course I had was phenomenal with a unique flair in taste and texture.

Came here with a dear friend for dinner and this was a first visit for us at a Michelin Star restaurant, and oh my... the food, the ambiance, the service were a match made in food heaven, it was truly an amazing experience.

Service

The wait staff were all extremely attentive, patient, and welcoming to all guests. We had our coats checked, and they immediately seated us. They were knowledgeable of all the courses on the menu and had great recommendations. The Sourdough bread was so scrumptious, that they did not mind to bring out more portions for us! The ambiance in this place is down right sexy, and classy, and all you want in a Michelin Star restaurant. We enjoyed every minute of our dinner experience and already planning to come back.

Food

Sourdough and miso-seaweed butter: Not an order, they do bring it out for you before the small plates/bites. The butter is.... ugh... no words to describe it. First off, the Sourdough bread comes PIPING HOT, you can see the steam coming out of the load as you unfold the cloth. The bread is soft and has a crispy crust. The butter just spreads on and melts into the bread, making it so addicting to eat. I had to stop myself because I would have gotten full just on the bread and butter. The wait staff was nice enough to offer more portions of the butter and bread.

Chu Toro: Had a really colorful display with the perfect amount of acidity from the Yuzu to pair with the fatty toro. This was also really refreshing at the same time. We could not get enough of the Yuzu and thoroughly enjoyed the flavors.

Australian Wagyu Beef: This was cooked to a perfectly medium rare (as requested) with rich umami flavor and scrumptious silky potato puree. The potato puree was so silky and you must smear it on top of the beef as you take your bite. The beef was so juicy and it was the right amount of tenderness that you do not need to chew.

Risotto: The risotto was definitely the biggest portion of the dishes overall, but it was not too ridiculously overly sized. The risotto could have used a bit more time to cook down, as some pieces were stuck to our teeth, but otherwise it was another delicious dish! It was just the right amount of creaminess, and a nice crunch from the cauliflower. We really enjoyed this and it came out piping hot, so it added points as we ate it. Really recommend this dish. It filled us up pretty good!

Lastly, we ordered the coconut tapioca (it comes in cold), with bing cherries (little cherry bites and the glaze), with mint. This was surprisingly good. The tapioca is packed underneath in a coconut cream (hardened), and the top is coated with the bing cherries and a glaze/jelly. The sweet, sour, tart, and creamy texture was so scrumptious and amazing end to our meal.

The drinks are also a must get as well (alcoholic and non-alcoholic).

Would definitely recommend for trying, thoroughly enjoyed our meals.

I always love going to trendy and hip places. Gives me a chance to dress up, feel young put on makeup and the best part is to have delicious food. Hubby booked this place after coming to a farewell party the week before. He was able to try the whole menu and already had his recommendations for me. Only the soft shell crab appetizer was a special that he didn't get to try at the party. We ordered the  Nori chips that was raw salmon rolled in two different types of tobiko on top of a dehydrated piece of seafood. So good and I always love the popping sensation of tobiko in all my food. We also ordered the hamachi crudo that came highly recommended by the waiter. Rolled up hamachi and pear in a flower shape topped with salmon roe in a light cream sauce. This dish was very light and refreshing. The pear added a slight sweetness to enhance the fish. Of course we had to order the soft shell crab even though we already decided on the dishes for our dinner. Did not disappoint. Lightly battered and very tasty on too of a chopped cabbage salad. The dressing almost tasted like Mayo and wasabi. For the entrees, we ordered the wagyu medium rare and the halibut. Both delightful and totally different dishes.

For cocktails, I ordered the Orion's Belt. It tasted very refreshing with the cucumbers-almost like a spa drink.

We had reservation for 9:15pm. Got there at 8pm to sit at the bar to enjoy drinks but a table was available right after we ordered or drinks so we moved to the table. I loved the table. There are three tables by the window that are like couple tables.  You gave the dining room and sit next to each other at an angle.

The sushi rice !!! I tried the restaurant week fix price menu and everything was sooo good! Although if I went again, I'd just get appetizers, the drinks were good but nothing special, the cheesecake was amazing

Came here for drinks and dessert  after having dinner at Rubirosa. I'm staying in the Dominick so it's was great to just come down here and have drinks and dessert with my gf. Deserts were amazing. Drinks were good too. Can't wait to come back for dinner.  Their cheese cake was so cute , crated like a piece of cheese and it was way better than juniors cheesecake. Trust.

Mentally dead from exhaustion, resurrected by Vestry.

Long day. Too tired to go out for dinner but was practically dying of hunger. A friend insisted. He picked this place and  forced to select menu for me.

Man... The food tastes so heavenly here. I felt my blood running mu body again and I could see things. InitialIy I thought my STUPID friend somehow chose three fish for a course. After meal, I think my DEAR friend loves me very much and worths a big praise.
Amazing place. What an I incredible blend of flavors.  Menu is very interesting and worth a try for anyone that loves seafood. If you are in the area drop by for a great dinner.

Trendy and modern vibe. Everything was amazing from presentation and the taste.

We ordered the warm oysters and chu toro as appetizers, halibut and cod as entrees and the cheesecake as dessert. Highly recommends the Warm oysters halibut and and cod; I'm picky with my seafood and I honestly loved every dish. All were very flavorful and different (with hints of Asian fusion). The two dishes were just okay; chu toro was over powered by the vegetables and then cheesecake was a little too sweet for my liking. But will definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone who loves seafood!  I will definitely be back to try the other dishes!

Very nice and clean bodega. Open 24/7. Prices are reasonable and food is satisfying. We got 2 paninis and the xyz wrap. The food definitely hit the spot and my friend started eating her wrap before we even got back. Highly recommend checking out this spot!

This place is incredibly expensive,and surprisingly doesn't offer veterans or seniors a discount why not? There are tons of employees,nurses,Residents,attendings,bus drivers ,vistors etc The other day they actually raised the prices 10 per cent,and didn't tell anyone until they got up to the cash register
Im going to give them 1 star for their pkg sushi which has all kinds of additives, you nbetter off asking the guy to make you some freshAlso on Fridays ahile they sell Fish its always super salty

This is a review of their retail service, they sell the same products as Best Buy and Walmart at incredible mark - ups. They claim to help Veterans but that is far from the truth . Just look up the reviews for this service, they should be run out of business for what they do to vets.

Easily the cheapest delicious meal in the area, this place serves authentic Mexican food right by Bellevue

Huitlacoche quesadilla was delicious with a good amount of filling. Bistek taco was fine.

Their tacos are 3.50 and so are their quesadillas so I'd skip the former and get 1/2 quesadillas.

Score is for the area

Fantastic!!! Fresh homemade tortillas made right as you order by the sweetest people. Food made with love and you can't go wrong with whatever you order. It is cash only BTW but super affordable and fast yummy lunch

I have to admit, Virgin Mary Tacos was actually cool. Very cute spot with great prices and good choices. Every single thing that I have ordered was really good and I would return to have it again! Service was amazing and everyone working here was very nice and hospitable. 10/10 would come back again to Virgin Mary Tacos and would recommend if you're in the area.

I asked the guy, and he said that the cart doesn't have a name. Then he suggested "Antiojos Mexicanos" which is just "Mexican Appetizers". That doesn't sound like much of a name at all. I propose people keep calling it Virgin Mary Tacos. Or Virgin Mary Quesadillas really, as that's their specialty. You can get a tinga one for three bucks. Beats any other quesadilla around here.
Two Carnitas tacos hit the spot. They have their own masa factory onsite. Will remember this one!

Absolutely 5 stars. The quesadillas are made with fresh homemade tortillas pressed on the spot.  Both the chorizo and the huitlacoche were fantastic. Super friendly people who run it. Cheap! Didn't try the zucchini flower one, will be back

Authentic tacos made right in front of you! She even makes the taco shells at the cart. We call her the taco lady. $10 for 3 steak tacos and a drink for lunch. She is not here in the Winter months. They only have a permit for the Summer months. The tacos are worth every penny. We eat tacos once a week in the Summer because of her - YUM!!

Absolutely delicious!! I went to try their food because they are literally across the street from my job and I wanted something rice so you can't got wrong with some Spanish food. Went there for lunch and got the Plato Special with Bistec and OMG! They got me. Forever. I finished the whole plate and dreamt about it the rest of the day! I felt so happy and satisfied. They give you a real good amount of food so you're not falling asleep or craving for more (even though I wanted more but that was me being greedy lol) and it's sooooo cheap!!!! Omg everything for $6! Usually I spend like over $10 for lunch. No wonder i see so many people stopping there to eat. And it's a cute tiny cart with the sweetest family! I found my new spot and I can't get over how delicious they are. Highly recommend it! I'm most likely going again tomorrow because when I love something so much I tend to obsess over it for a long time lol.
Service was great but food was just about ok. The seating arrangements were not comfortable and pretty weird
Very nice restaurant. Really enjoyed it. I like the service of the waitress nadiya. I definitely recommend this restaurant.
Gujarati village ambiance, romantic and relaxing, prix fixe meal price, strictly vegetarian.

We had a fantastic time when we visited this place while visiting NYC. Totally different experience and food was amazing.

Service and Ambiance was equally deserves 5 * rating. Will visit again on our next trip next week.

Ananth

Service is great, the place has a nice ambience, but the food is just OK.

This is suppose to be a gujrati thali place - "flavors of Gujarat" as they call it out on the website, but paneer, chole cannot be called gujarati flavors. There were very few select items that came close to being gujarati food - the daal and the kadhi. Appetizer course was good, main course was OK. Dessert was just fine - gulab jamun and malai ice cream. Amras was just something poured out of a can. One other thing I didn't appreciate was -- the food was lukewarm when it was brought to the table.

Our hostess - Divisha - was good - attentive service with a smile :D

Not worth it for vegans. In this day and age, they're still catering to vegans by omission. They remove the yoghurt from the appetizers which have them before serving them to you along with the items completely if they have dairy in them. In the entree round again, they did not have any swaps for dairy based items (kheer being one of them). Forget about dessert as all three are non vegan and their solution is to give you aam rus which is mango pulp sweetened with sugar. I couldn't take more than a bite of it, it was like eating straight up sugar. That is a part of the entree round itself but they "saved" it so they can say that they have 1 item for us for dessert.
The service was mediocre with our server rushing us to get the refills.
The little food that we ate was good but you definitely do not get what you pay for if you're vegan.

I've been meaning to try out Vatan for a while now after seeing it across social media. I came on a Monday night at 7 PM with a group of three. Reservations were very easy to make on Yelp.

We were seated in the bottom portion. For the tables they require you to take off your shoes to enter the seating area. The seats were wooden benches with some cushions on top and pretty comfortable. The decorations within the restaurant were beautiful and intricately decorated.

The restaurant serves all you can eat pre-fixe menu with items for appetizers, mains and desserts. Every item can be refilled as many times as you want. They give you as much time to each each course as you want and do not rush you at all.

The food was great! There were a few items I was not a big fan of but apart from that everything was lovely. So many selections to try out.

Service itself was also wonderful. Our server, Divisha, was very friendly and really helped to make the meal an enjoyable time.

All in all, a great experience. $45/person is very reasonable for all you get and I can't wait to come back soon.

I had heard so much about Vatan for months before finally being able to make a visit. I had heard that Vatan served Thail-style meals but I had no idea that it was an all-you-can-eat meal. For $45, this is one of the best AYCE meal deals in the city. There are much quality Indian cooking in Manhatten in Manhatten but Vatan is definitely one of the better spots.

We started with the appetizer thali which included many different items including samosa, ragda pattice, channa, bhajis, and our favorite dahi puri topped with sev. The appetizers were very flavorful and the condiments which they provided were also very tasty.

For the main course, there were too many items to count, all served with rice, khadi, and khichdi and accompanied by puri and roti. There were so many main course items but the best was the Channa Masala and the Okra masala.

We finished the meal with dessert which was malai ice cream and gulab jamun. Our server Harsh was very knowledgeable about the menu and knew all the dishes and allergens as well. All in all, Vatan was a great experience and for the price, one of the best meal deals in NYC.
Service was very good. Rest wasn't impressive at all. Food and ambiance was pretty mediocre. It was a clean place.

This is an incredible vegetarian (or vegan) dining experience! It's a really cool dining atmosphere, and we had the most pleasant, accommodating, and funny waitress you could imagine. Everything is all-you-can-eat; they bring out a platter of appetizers for each guest that they will replenish at your request followed by a thali of entrees (curries, papadam, and roti) that are also bottomless. Everything is accompanied by rice pulao and khichdi (possibly the tastiest part of the meal?!) The meal is finished out with desserts and chai. There were plentiful vegan options for every course. I didn't feel like I was missing out on anything except maybe the dessert (we just got warm cardamom tea and some mango purée). Nevertheless, Vatan is one of my top meal experiences in the city.

Harsh was an excellent server and very helpful.
We enjoyed our dinner and relived our recent trip to India.

Bindu was our server-top notch
Great food but don't stuff yourself with the appetizers, there's more to come
One of my absolute favorite spots. Amazing food and great service. Shout out to Bin for being so lovely!

Vatan was catering at one of the events in Philadelphia expo center. The food was not worth the price they were charging. Worst is the integrity of the staff. They forgot to give me the change and when I mention it they brushed me off. It was not about the money but about the integrity of the staff. Would not hire they for any event.
B was such an amazing server thank you for such a great night with incredible food as always!

2023/08/24 - Thursday dinner. My dad is Gujarati, so I had high expectations for this place and it genuinely delivered. Most of the food was familiar, but the sheer amount of options, and the ability to reorder anything made it really special. I was almost full from the appetizers alone - Muthia was great, and their Batata Vada is genuinely a contender for the best I've had outside of India, ever. Standout from the main course was Kadhi, but everything was excellent. The Chai we received during dessert was also great. The servers were excellent and explained what each item was really well, even if we didn't need it. Despite being told the food was 'Indian spicy, not American spicy,' it wasn't spicy enough for me, except for the Mirchi Bhajia. Overall, a really great experience.

However...

Our group included one member who was gluten-free and vegan. It was great that they had a preset menu for this specific diet, and some of the substitutions were better than the regular meal. But not everything was substituted. The gluten-free thali didn't include Roti or Puri, and didn't include a substitute bread, even though there was a gluten-free Rotla available as an extra order. The gluten-free menu was the same price as standard even though it removed some items without replacement, and then charged extra for the replacement. That is unreasonable, especially at the price point of this restaurant.

Additionally, it would've been nice if a drink was included in the meal, since a real traditional Gujarati meal would likely include Chaas, and many similar restaurants do.

Leave the hustle and bustle of Manhattan behind and get transported to a beautiful Indian Courtyard at Vatan. Get a warm welcome as you prepare to enjoy a delicious vegetarian thali feast.

Vatan celebrates the flavors of Gujarat. Take off your shoes and coat and have a seat at a beautiful booth or low table with cushions on the floor. Enjoy the ambiance of a typical Indian Courtyard. Love the 20-foot-tall banyan tree. Look for the cute monkey sitting high up on a branch. The hand painted tables are so beautiful. The thatched roofs and clouds in the sky make you think that you are in India.

The menu is an authentic prix fixe thali which includes an appetizer thali, an entree thali, entree compliments, desserts and masala chai. They are Kosher certified and can accommodate dietary or other religious restrictions like Jain, Swaminarayan/Vaishnav, vegan, nut-free and gluten free.  The entree can be ordered mild, moderate or spicy.

The service was perfect. Our hostess explained each course. It felt like our party of six was a guest at someone's home. Bring a hearty appetite as there is a delicious variety. Seconds or more are included.

Favorites appetizers included the savory samosas and muthia which was so unique. The batata vada were fried balls of potato deliciousness. The sev puri was so rich with the combination of the yogurt and chutney.

The entrees were also amazing. Our group had seconds of the bhaji, choli, and batakanu sak. The ful-cobi was a definite favorite. The cauliflower was so flavorful. The sweetness of the kheer, rice pudding with dried fruit, balanced the savory dishes. Loved the khichdi which I had not tried before.

Finished the meal with masala chai, my favorite tea, a decadently delicious gulab juman and a couple of Indian ice creams.

The meal is $45 plus tax and tip. You are paying for a delicious meal and the beautiful ambiance. Perfect for a special treat with family and friends.  

Appetizer Thali included:
CHANA MASALA- chickpeas with onions and coriander.
KHAMAN- puffed cream of wheat flour cakes.
MUTHIA-steamed flour with spinach.
MIRCHI BHAJIA-fried hot peppers with garam masala.
BATATA VADA- fried potato balls in a chickpea batter.
RAGDA PATIS-potato cutlet in a white bean sauce.
SEV PURI-potatoes, green beans, yogurt and chutney filled in a crispy bread.
SAMOSA- savory pastries filled with potatoes and onions.

Entree Thali included:
TOOR DAL-lentils with Indian spices
BHAJI-sautéed spinach and corn.
FUL-COBI- cauliflower and green peas sautéed in a savory sauce.
BATAKANU SAK-potatoes cooked in a mild red gravy.
CHOLE-chickpeas in a garam masala sauce.
PURI-puffed whole what bread.
ROTI-whole wheat flatbread.
PAPADAM-thin lentil wafers.
KHEER- rice pudding with dried fruits.
AAM RUS-mango pulp (available upon request).
PULAO- white rice with peas.
KHICHDI-lentils mixed with rice and vegetables.
KADHI-yogurt soup.

DESSERT AND CHAI
ICE CREAM- Mango and Indian Ice Cream
GULAB JAMUN- decadently delicious waffle balls in a sugar and rose syrup.
MASALA CHAI-Indian tea with cardamom, ginger and milk.

Good experience with the three course- appetizer, main, and dessert thaali. Each course had only a select few items that were enjoyable to my palette.

I am an Indian who likes spice so this was a little lacking in some of the items even though I chose the maximum spice level on the scale offered by the server. However, the service was great and food seemed freshly prepared too.

The appetizers course standouts were the dahi chaat and upma sort of dish. The rest was average.
In the mains, I enjoyed only two of the several dishes presented too.

The dessert course was a little underwhelming with the ice cream bit of it while I would have preferred something more traditional to the culture represented by the cuisine served at Vatan.

The overall experience was okay, closer to good, but a little more effort and this concept could be unstoppable.

Wow, the food is hospitality is amazing here! VR was an incredible waitress server. She explained to us every dish and she took great care of the details for my food especially because I eat Vegan and I have a gluten allergy. Next time I visit NY, I will definitely come back here and bring my friends again. Love the ambiance here as well

My favorite Indian restaurant in New York City. The food, the ambiance, the service, are all wonderful. On my most recent visit, I and my party were greeted by our server, Harsh, and treated to a description of every menu item on our plates. Yes, you get everything on the menu, in small enough portions to enjoy them all, yet enough to feel pleasantly full. I will be back, again.
Great service from Divisha, and really tasty food - and so much of it - for a super reasonable price.
Great food and great service from VR! The meal was very filling and the service was very thorough!

This was an incredible experience. It's a vegetarian prix fixe unlimited menu with an appetizer course, entree course, and dessert. Each course is a thali (array of small dishes) and you can order more of any dish you like. I also had masala chaas for a drink. All of the dishes were very tasty - my favorites were the poori, sev puri, sambar, and gulab jamun. Each dish had a unique blend of flavors and textures, and everything is of very high quality. The decor is also very unique, with paintings of rural scenes all over the walls. Come hungry!

Let me break down this experience. First off, when you reserve, make sure you reserve an area in the bottom floor; near all the glorious structures and religious pieces. It's beautiful but they're in hot demand.

The food is AYCE and flavorful. I haven't had better thalis in NYC, and I'd give the food a 9/10. Samosas, chana, and daal were stand outs. Mango iced cream a revelation.

Service was the best I've ever had. Kind waiter. Prompt. Explained all the dishes.

Amazing experience
We love coming to Vatan and every time we eat here it's the best experience. Bin gave us incredible service our last time we were here. Great food. Great atmosphere. Great service.
Ambiance and taste of food is good. Service seemed ok for the fine dine experience paid for.

Came for dinner on a weeknight around 7:30 and the place was relatively busy - would be best to get a reservation if you have your heart set on eating here.

It's all you can eat at a set price - so a ton of food... but it's pretty expensive.
Food wise, everything was pretty good, not the best I've had, but I enjoyed the ability to try so many dishes in a single meal

Decor is nice, they have an upstairs and a downstairs, seems like the downstairs would be better!

If you're new to Indian food, and Gujarati food at that, this is a great place to go for a 1 time experience

Hmmm...so hard to leave only 3 stars but for us the food was just so so. But the service was great and they are sooooo welcoming and lovely! For us there were so many unique dishes but somehow they all tasted the same to us. A LOT of chickpeas and lentils and a ton of starches - very few vegetables. There just wasn't anything that wowed us and for Indian that was very surprising. But go an make your own decision the space is cute and the staff are exceptional.
Good food. Our server Navya was really attentive and kind, as was everyone who worked there!

Vatan is a fantastic spot in midtown for an all you can eat Indian experience. Generally speaking, I've been pretty disappointed with the quality of Indian food in NYC as the standards I'm used to from the London was so much higher. Vatan is by far my favorite Indian spot in NYC.

It wasn't just the food, the whole experience was just fantastic. The ambience, the decor inside (upon entering you feel as though you are transported to another city or place), the service (our waiter was extremely knowledgable, patient and polite), the price ($45 for AYCE!) and most importantly the food - despite being AYCE, I personally could not eat more than 1 serving of each dish (which was many) because I was so full! The variety was such a nice touch - you get just enough of everything to try it without feeling stuffed.

I also loved how they accommodate so many different dietary needs - gluten free, vegan, non diary etc. Just to note, it is a vegetarian restaurant, though this really did not matter. Not once during my meal did I feel like I was missing meat.

I can't wait to go back and bring a few more friends with me.

Excellent service
Sumptuous food
Beautiful ambiance

Very polite and friendly staff.  This is the first time we  felt confident about having our nut allergic kid eat worry-free in a restaurant.  They had an entire platter from starters to dessert for customers with nut allergy.

very unique authentic experience. I've really never seen anything like this. Feels like you're going into some kind of Indian village. Some of the tables you'll sit right on the ground with pillows which is pretty cool. Special shoutout to our waiter who was the sweetest auntie. I felt like the food was coming straight from someone's own kitchen.

For $45 you get a pre fixe menu with apps/entree/dessert. The whole spread is delicious with so many interesting bites. You get to refill any that you finish and want seconds of as well. I was totally stuffed at the end. Not one bad dish.

I'd definitely recommend if you want a unique and authentic experience. Good for friends or families.

Vegetarian thali was amazing

Place is very busy! Be aware - it is all you can eat however if you get through everything one time you likely can't eat anymore!
Highly recommended!! The food and service was amazing! Our server Harsh was very helpful and described all the dishes served. We can't wait to return with friends!

Finally a great indian restaurant with awesome food, service and ambience! AND VEGETARIAN! They offered a fully nut free buffet for my allergic kid which was every bit as delicious! I haven't heard of any other Indian restaurant that does this. The service was awesome and  they assured me to eat "worry free". Great work Vatan!!

I didn't know what to expect when a friend made reservations to Vatan but it ended up being a very unique vegetarian prix fixe ayce experience (currently $45pp). First, the ceilings are very high and they used the height wisely with a life-size fake tree and giant Ganesh statue in the back and wall to wall murals. Second, you take your shoes off by the table and sit on cushioned benches. Then our waitress was a sweet auntie who explained everything to us and made sure we had no allergies.

It's a 3 course meal (appetizer thali, entree thali, and dessert with Chai) with a lot of variety. Everything comes in a cafeteria style tray with a little bit of everything listed on the menu. Then you're able to order more of what you like. There's no time limit and you don't feel rushed. I personally preferred the appetizer dishes more than the entree dishes. There was just more flavor and textures. Only downside to this is that most dishes are grain and starch based (chickpeas, lentils, potatoes) and they fill you up quick so you can't take advantage of the AYCE aspect as we were all pretty full from our first serving.

Very good food from the western india- Gujarati Cuisine. The service was also excellent our sever name was Payal , she was extremely attentive and very pleasant. Please reserve the table before going there . We were asked to remove footwear and sit  in crossed leg seating- traditional Indian seating for eating meal. They serve the 3 course meal - appetizers, main course and then dessert. We were stuffed in the first course it self. I would definitely recommend this place and visit again when in New York city.

My love for Indian Thali (unlimited food) is unwavering, there's an assortment of food for you to try on, everything from savory to sweet to deserts, along with unlimited quantity to fuel your hunger. Vatan, naturally, caught my attention when it presented itself as a Thali place. I made reservation (highly recommended) for a Monday dinner. The place is very well laid out and has an antic vibe with graphics from ancient India. The colors and the paintings represent the past very well. The entire restaurant has dim lighting which I felt went well with the decor.

Talking about the food now, I'll first point out that the price was exorbitant for a vegetarian Thali ($45 per person with 20% gratuity + taxes). This was one  of the most expensive Thali restaurant that i've ever eaten at. They have appetizers, entree and deserts all very well described in the menu. They have a drinks menu as well which is worth keeping an eye out for. At first, you are introduced to the appetizer Thali which has fried, baked and chaat options. The star of this Thali was Sev Puri along with Ragda Patis (to some extent). You can have unlimited servings of any dishes you like. The next Thali is the Entree Thali and here Chole Puri and Kheer were the clear favorites. The Dal was a typical sweet dal which I didn't enjoy and the Spinach Bhaji and Ful-Cobi were just ok. Aam Rus was the biggest miss for me, this is available upon request so do request one if you wanna try this (I obviously did), the flavor was just not there and it tasted like a supermarket frozen aam rus. For Deserts (at this point, we were pretty full) we ordered one Gulab Jamun and Masala Chai and you have to try the Chai. It had a tantalizing aroma and was spiced aptly.

The service was good and restaurant has a unique seating arrangement which is well thought off. The reservation system is handled by Yelp which was a hassle free experience. There is no dedicated parking which should be expected for a NYC restaurant.

Vatan serves all you can eat Thali food with a great ambiance. For $45 + tax and gratuity, would I say it was worth the money? NO. I understand this is New York and the prices are inflated and such, but for that price point, the food wasn't comparable. Only a few items on this entire Thali journey were worth recommending (which I outlined) and everything else could be skipped entirely. I would however, rate this place a B-, despite the shortcomings, the restaurant does brilliantly with it's service and decor along with the fresh and hot puri and home style phulka roti which pairs brilliantly with some entrees. The puri and aamrus combo was a major blow and the Dal had the typical Gujarati sweet flavor which I couldn't enjoy. The restaurant is worth a try if you have an inclination towards Gujarati food.

This place is incredible!! We loved it. The food is incredible. It's an authentic experience. Our server Royal was also so professional and helpful and made our experience. I will recommend this place to everyone.
Always a fun time here. Food is good. Staff are all very nice. Interior design is quite the experience.

The ambience and service at this place was excellent. However, the food was incredibly average. The channa we had for the appetizer was incredibly salty. The ragda patis and muthia could have, on the other hand, used more salt. The dal and the kadhi were good. Being from Houston, we have much better Gujarati thali places this so I found this sub par. I do want to give a shout out to our server, Karan, who was excellent and very attentive.

I used to live near this restaurant. So I've dined here several times over the years. It's my favorite Indian restaurant in NYC. The dishes are always delicious and have the perfect amount of spice/hotness. I love that I don't have to select any one dish because all of them are served. It's a great place to enjoy different types of Indian dishes if you aren't familiar with food on an Indian menus. The atmosphere/decorations make you feel like you've been transported to another city.

So why not give five stars? The service wasn't very attentive. After sitting there for what felt like too long, she finally took our drink order. The drinks arrived after the appetizer was served. At one point I had asked if we could put in our drink order, while waking away from our table she said let me put in your appetizer order first. Maybe it's just me, but don't drinks typically arrive before food?

To end on a positive note, the meal also comes with two types of rice, creamy mango ice cream and tea. Make sure you arrive hungry because it's a ton of amazing food!

Prix fixe menu, with all you can eat vegetarian Gujarati
Food.  Food and service was excellent.  One piece of advice, don't eat anything all day, and come hungry!

The decor I believe is designed after a small Indian village, with a Banyan tree, Ganesh and a blue sky above.  Over all a delightful place to eat delicious food!

Excessively spicy bordering on un-edible. Vegan options are configured by eliminating items instead of substitutions.  They keep hovering around the table asking you to settle the check so that they can turn tables perhaps.  Disappointing.

First time going on a recommendation of a friend. Pre-fixed menu of appetizers, entrees and desserts, for a reasonable price. Especially in NYC. Very nice decor and staff was attentive and informative on questions we had and about each individual serving. Everything was excellent.  I had two of Everything and did not make it to dessert. 100 percent vegan selections and seasoned perfect. I went medium then hot on my servings. It is now in my rotation and will bring friends!

While the restaurant's ambiance was pleasant and the service was attentive, the food itself left much to be desired. The flavors seemed lackluster and failed to capture the vibrant and authentic taste I was hoping for, especially in Gujarati cuisine. The dishes lacked the depth and complexity that I associate with Gujarati flavors, and the overall execution felt underwhelming.

I was particularly disappointed with the quality of the appetizers (farshan). The frozen Indian foods available in the market seemed to bring more authenticity than the food at Vatan. For example, the dahi wada's dahi tasted like shrikhand, and the mirchi bhajji contained pickled chili (vadhawani marcha), which was unexpected.

Even the main courses, such as the Gujarati dal and kadhi, lacked the rich flavors I have come to expect from Gujarati cuisine. Comparing Vatan to other Gujarati thali-serving restaurants in Surat like Sasuma and Kansar, or even the cheaper Gujarati restaurants in Anand-Nadiad-Vidhyanagar during my college days, Vatan's taste was not even comparable.

Additionally, I ordered a cocktail called Mango Mirchi, which was disappointing. It neither had the taste of mango nor mirchi. It felt like drinking stale vodka with tap water.

Despite the disappointing food, I must commend the staff for their friendly and prompt service. They were attentive and responsive to our needs. However, the subpar quality of the food overshadowed this positive aspect.

I hope Vatan takes this feedback constructively to improve the quality and flavors of their dishes, bringing them closer to the authentic and vibrant Gujarati cuisine that customers expect.

Vatan is an extraordinary representation of regional authenticity in Indian cuisine - Gujarati food. This isn't some hole in the wall, but quite a spacious, architecturally beautiful and soul satisfying restaurant.

The moment you walk in, you are charmed by the village style decor of Gujarat. The unlimited prix fixed menu is the way to go - lots of Appetizers, main course & desserts to fill you up. Each item has a unique taste and is mostly healthy, vegetarian food. I am from Gujarat & can vouch for this place as authentic.

At $50pp, it ain't cheap but overall worth the pleasant experience.

Our server Varshitha went above and beyond! They even made delicious speciality cocktails for us. Love the place. Food was delicious, people were so kind and welcoming. Ambience was perfect. Lots of private tables. Would highly recommend! Can't wait to go again!
A hidden gem! Eating here is like getting a home-cooked meal at your Gujarati auntie's house. My wife is guju and this is her favorite place to eat in the city. You won't be disappointed!

Food is not bad but the serving style is terrible. This is not the way to serve a thaali. Please do not kill the traditional style of serving thali. Bring all the appetizers, main course & desserts in one go. No one likes waiting for minutes while eating thaali.

I was starving after an appointment and this spot is the first thing that I saw. I had a personal pizza (was starving so no pics) and a house salad. The dressing for the salad was delicious. Like I need them to bottle it. The pizza was thin and so cheesy. I didn't think that I would have enough room to eat it all but it was so good that I couldn't stop.

The service was great. Staff seemed friendly. I chose to eat inside. They have a bar, tables and booths. It looks like a pizzeria with a flair. They also have outside seating. If I am ever in the area again, I will come back .

Terrific pizza here. I had the chance to order from the lunch special menu, but for three people, it made more sense to get a large house pie and share a salad.

We got the Meat Lover's large size $37.50 and the house salad $12. The portion size was perfect for three people. We cleared everything. It was great to eat a thin-slice pizza in New York. I got an Arnold Palmer, and the server offered not to put too much sugar. It was def more on the sour side, but it was good nonetheless.

Service was superb.

Not impressed. Very pricey and very stingy on the toppings. Virtually NO sauce. They gave me pepperoni instead of the eggplant I ordered.

You pay extra for sauce and just about everything else because the initial price is just for the crust and cheese evidently. Very strange.

Not much flavor because there was hardly any sauce.

Will not be ordering again. C'mon, this is NYC and there is better pizza.

I grew up in an Italian neighborhood in Brooklyn and I miss the good stuff very much.

And damn it, who the hell pays for the sauce on pizza. Gimme a break.

Love this pizzeria!!

The house salad is a staple. Must have!!!
Mesclun greens, olives, red onions, cherry tomatoes, mushrooms and house dressing. Amazing!!! I can eat plates of it.

Shrimp linguine. Just enough portion, butter lemon garlic white wine. Gone in minutes.

Attentive and hospitable staff.

Great spot to grab a quick bite to eat. This was an amazing little find! They only
Server wine and beer, but will be expanding their menu. It was a nice surprise. My husband and I enjoyed everything!

Got some last minute reservations for the family on Resy because the person responsible for finding is a nice Italian restaurant got us to a takeout pizza slice joint.

This was a pleasant replacement with outdoor seating.

I had a cauliflower crust spicy marinara and pepperoni pizza with a Greek salad to start.

Others had plain and pepperoni thin crust pizza.

This is super thin crust pizza and not for everyone. It's easy to eat a whole pie by yourself.

Service was a bit slow and overwhelmed, so getting their attention outside is extra tough. With kids in the party, we had to frequently get up for things we needed or to find our waiter. He worked hard, but it was tough for us.

There are two bathrooms inside and they each had lines the whole time.  

Remember to tip well. They work hard.

On our New York visit, kids wanted to get thin crust pizza, so I wanted to try this for lunch. We were seated and served drinks, and the waiter gave an overview of the options. The ambiance is very good  and they have a nice bar area too.  We ordered lemonade and pizza with peppers topping. The service was fast, and the pizza tasted delicious and still remembered the flavor and thin crust was perfect. It's probably one of the best pizzas I had recently . I will try this place again for sure when I visit New york.

Pizza is my weakness. I love it all. Deep dish, thick crust, Greek doughy, spicy, sweet.

And, of course, thin crust! And did I find the finish crust around or what?

Since I'm dieting, I was very good and ordered a salad and had once slice, with a  glass of red wine. Although the apple salad with cheddar and pumpkin seeds looks very simple,  the homemade dressing made it perfectly delicious and I ate every bit of it. The wait staff was very attentive at this cozy little pizza parlor. And the playlist was very cool! We heard some Frank Ocean and Tame Impala which impressed my teens.

It's definitely hard to choose which pizza to have when you're in New York but I'll be coming back here on my next trip. I would love to try their spicy sauce. They also offer gluten free.

I have no good reason why it took me so long to finally come here and try the Shroomtown pizza, so all I will say is thank god for holiday serendipity and not making a resy anywhere else on a busy Saturday night.

The Shroomtown pizza was everything this fungus lover could ask for. The Rotella app was the prosciutto sushi I never knew I needed in life (and MUST have on a consistent basis henceforth). And the Milanesa, while overshadowed by the previous two, held its own for fresh, veggie goodness.

Combine all that with warm brick walls and candlelight, and you've got a winner for dinner. Thin crust will always be greater than thick crust, and Vezzo might just be the best of its kind in NYC.

It was my friend's birthday and he suggested this place. This was actually my second time coming here.

My friend made reservations here. Once we entered we got seated promptly. The place was pretty dim but not too dim. We ended up ordering  the classica margherita ($28) and the salsiccia dolce ($32). Both were delicious. What stood out was the thin crust. The slices are not too heavy, I was able to eat 4 slices.

I would highly recommend this place if you're in the mood for a sit down pizza meal or on a date.

* Pro-tip: when picking the slice from the pizza pan, slide the slice to your plate (slices don't hold up well)

* great service
* they take reservations
* they DO NOT sell by the slice

Great thin crust pizza. This place meets all the needs and wants when you're craving a crispy, thin crust pizza that has the right balance of sauce and cheese as well. The fresher the better, but this pizza travels well. Have dined in and had it delivered. Crispy-ness holds up and flavors work well. Shroom town is my favorite but go with what you're craving, you won't be disappointed. Only knock is their choice on peppers (feel too thick/rustic of a cut for the type of pizza)

Don't forget to try and start with the salad. This pizza place has some great options that should not be slept on. Weird to recommend when reviewing a pizza spot, but worth it.

This is not your typical NYC pizza with a thick crust and a loaded with cheese and sauce. Vezzo serves a thin, crispy pizza that you would find in Rome. With that in mind, they do it well! They have a personal size pizza that is good for one person and a larger 16 inch pizza that can feed two or three depending on your appetite. Their pizza is very flavorful and the crispy taste is a nice change from the typical floppy pizzas.

I only had their pizza but this a full service Italian restauarant with a complete menu. You can also get salads, pasta, and a large selection of appetizers from here too. And there is a bar as well.

Vezzo is a delightfully cute restaurant with shady outdoor seating.

Pizza is very thin crust and not necessarily the traditional NY style pizza you'd be looking for.

A sit-down restaurant, Service is slow but I think that this is the kind of restaurant for a bottle of wine and leisurely meal.

1 unisex bathroom. Clean.

I love thin crust pizza. This stuff literally goes down like water. You can just keep eating and eating it's like you never get full, and Vezzo executes it excellently. They have such a big variety of pizzas, and we ended up trying four of them.

We were originally going to get four personal pies, but the waiter recommended getting two regular pizzas and getting two variations per pizza (half of one type and half of another). There were four of us, and that meant there were four slices of each, which was perfect. I will say that they came out slightly on the saltier side (so all that stuff about me saying the pizza goes down like water-- yeah, it's true, but it also requires water in order to consume).

We also got some appetizers and salad to share. The spinach salad was SO good. Am a big fan of sweet and salty salads and this 100% delivered.

In the end, my favorite pizza was the Big Pineapple!

Got the small Big Pineapple pizza for takeout along with the Spinach Salad, perfect for 2 people!

Loved the thin-crust and flavor of the pizza; there were multiple enticing combo options but I was craving pineapple on pizza. The bacon on the pizza was just a little dry/too hard for my personal liking. Got the spinach salad per the recent reviews on Yelp--so good! The pecans, pear, feta cheese and tart lemon-basil vinaigrette made for a delicious salad (I normally don't like just spinach in salad).

Overall a great meal and would come back for more!!

Super delicious personal pizzas at a reasonable price, I am definitely going to become a regular at thIs spot.
